subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more
Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We conducted 2 researches that served as a reference for measuring participation in Governance:

Token House Participation and Incentives: Season 5 (Cycles 16-19), captures essential data on delegate participation and provides a condensed overview of governance during Season 5. It analyzes the Collective's evolution, highlighting significant findings such as a increase in mission proposals and a rise in active delegate participation, while noting a decline in mission approval rates, which may suggest a more rigorous selection process. 

Big Picture: The Grants Council, documents the evolution of the Grants Council, emphasizing its transition from a governance experiment to a vital structure within Optimism. This report details the Council's efforts to streamline grant distribution, enhance transparency, and improve fund management, offering a chronological and quantifiable perspective on its activities, structure, budget allocations, and results over the seasons.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The Token House Participation and Incentives served as a guide for the Foundation to determine the Retro Delegate Rewards for Season 5. While the Grants Council report was included as part of the govNERDs contribution path.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
CharmVerse powered the end to end grants process of the Grants Council, servicing a total of 1,171 applications across Season 5 and 6. The process includes application intake, Council evaluation, communication & notifications, and milestone tracking. 

Over the past 12 months, monthly active users ranged from ~1k to 4.4k. In Cycle 19, NPS from finalist was 9/10, exceeding target of 7/10, indicating high satisfaction levels among applicants with the grants process. 

"Special acknowledgment is due to the Charmverse team for their instrumental role in providing the necessary tools to facilitate the review process. Leveraging the rubric, workflow, and form tools for the first time, we achieved an impressive success rate of 97.2% out of 314 applications without errors and solved any issues on a 12-hour gap" - Gonna, Grants Council Lead

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
We work closely with the Grants Council and constantly evolve the platform to meet their specific needs and ensure great grantee experience in a timely manner. Both the Grants Council and grant applicants benefit from a transparent and efficient grants process. 

"We are delighted to announce that rubric comments are now integrated directly into your applications. Simply navigate to your application and check the sidebar to find scores for each rubric section, along with comments from reviewers. A huge thanks to the Charmverse team for implementing this feature so quickly." - Gonna, Grants Council Lead

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Our DAO has 159 unique members who have provided us with 131k OP votes. We follow new proposals every day and have participated in almost every vote.

In order to attract this number of users, we held various events and engaged in media outreach. We have also done a lot of work with CIS Influencers, so the number of participants and the amount has increased several times since PRGF3.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer: The number of active DAO participants increased from 93 to 159 and the amount from 38k to 131k OP. So we can confidently say that we have done a great job in increasing the decentralization of the network over the last year.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history
Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Lighthouse native mobile app makes it easy for Citizens and Delegates to participate in Optimism governance. We built support for Optimism's custom Governor contract, which enabled us to add multiple powerful new features:

1. We've added real time push notifications of new proposal and voting activity. 

2. We've added the ability to vote on proposals, on-chain, natively from within the Lighthouse app. 

3. We also pulled in on-chain comments and displayed them within the app, to surface community sentiment around proposals for users.

4. Our interactive Farcaster Frames integration enables on-chain proposals and comments to be shared, further increasing awareness and participation in the social media space.

This all works together to provide a powerful and feature-complete alternative client for users who wish to vote on the go.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Token holders, delegates and followers benefit by Optimism being on Lighthouse. Even users who do not hold Optimism tokens are able to follow core Optimism proposal activity, making Optimism governance more accessible throughout the ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer: The Security Council carried out its role of signing protocol upgrades approved by the Token House in accordance with the Internal Operating Procedures set out by the council. In Season 6 the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1, where the Foundation multisig was removed from the Upgrade multisig, and the Security Council became the sole signer.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
In Season 6, the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1. A requirement for Phase 1 is that a 75% signing threshold is met for all upgrades. This requires 10 out of 13 signatures. Security Council members continued to engage swiftly when action was required. The following upgrades were signed during Season 6:

### Protocol Upgrade 10 — Granite Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: September 6 - September 10
🥳 Status: Executed September 11 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 9 — Fjord Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: June 26 - July 2
🥳 Status: Executed July 10 with 12/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 8 — Changes for Stage 1 Decentralization
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 7 — Fault Proofs
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: The Retro Funding Review Tool enables application reviewers to ensure that all Retro Funding applications voted on by badge holders met eligibility criteria, prior to voting. The tool facilitated Retro Funding Round 4 & 5's application review process. Prior to CharmVerse, reviews were coordinated using complicated excel sheets where the core team spent countless hours in an error-prone process.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
All badge holder reviews for Retro Funding 4 and 5 were conducted on CharmVerse. The processes supported 416 applications with 271 applications approved. 46 Reviewers leveraged the platform to conduct their reviews. 

The tool saved the core team countless hours. It streamline the process and save time for the 46 reviewers. Finally, all applicants benefited from the result of a better run process with higher transparency and reduced bias and errors.

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
There were three goals for the DAB in Season 5, as laid out in the [initial forum post](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board/6892):

1) Assess and approve Delegate Mission Request 13 drafts based on their technical merits 
2) Aid the Grants Council in assessing approved Delegate Mission Requests and Mission Applications 13 under Intent #1
3) Advise the Grants Council in assessing the completion of technical milestones

Additionally, there was one implicit goal:

4) Act as a test run to determine whether the DAB is a useful part of Optimism Governance, explore additional ways to help, and formalize processes for future seasons.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
On the explicit goals:
- All Mission Requests were reviewed by multiple DAB members, who provided that input to the community in order to determine the right MRs to fund.
- All applications to the Grants Council under Intent #1 received feedback from 2+ DAB members to help better allocate funds. 
- Additionally, the DAB expanded our scope to provide input on all requested applications, not just Intent #1, a learning that has carried over to future seasons.
- The DAB also began to give feedback on the funding amount, which resulted in 100k+ OP being saved by governance due to more appropriate funding.

Additionally, on the implicit goal, the experiment of having a Developer Advisory Board was a great success. It was renewed for Season 6 with an expanded scope, and has continued to deliver important results.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We have created a comprehensive analysis of Optimism Badgeholder's onchain activity vs a control group of active non-Badgeholders. In particular, we looked at transaction activity across chains, involvement in social apps (Farcaster, Lens, Friendtech), participation in other DAOs (Arbitrum, Uniswap, ENS) and the deployment of smart contracts and NFTs. 

Something to note: although it is true that not all citizens use their Badgeholder address for other onchain activity, we found that a significant amount did and we discuss the implications of this constraint in the report.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation. This work was requested directly by the Foundation in order to get a better understanding of Optimism Badgeholders vs “normal” Ethereum users. In their own words: “In order to confidently expand the Citizenry, we need to have a baseline understanding of the current Badgeholder group. Our goal is to get a better understanding of the Badgeholder group based on their onchain activity compared with the onchain activity of other active Optimism/Ethereum users.”

In addition, the entire Optimism Collective has benefitted from the transparency provided by this publicly available work. It's open source nature sets the stage for others to conduct further research and expand upon our results.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Now we’ve analyzed ~200 OP citizens (delegates and projects data is being processed now as well), and their connections over 10 data sources (Farcaster, on-chain attestations, token holdings and community association, more: https://govgraph.fyi/connection-types). The intention was to understand the nature of relations inside of the house, identify the centers of influence, and support matchmaking for the alliances. We’ve identified 9 other potential use cases for the tool: https://govgraph.fyi/use-cases.

Some Insight from the current study:
- lindaxie.eth (followed by 88 citizens), w.jesse.xyz (86), purple.philm.eth (75), 0x91...5871 (75), vitalik.eth (74) are the most followed accounts on Farcaster
- Only 19 people (~10%) have no identified connections
- Potential connections within the Regen movement – 49 people (~25%)

This work led us also to explore the Sybil algorithms for the Farcaster, where we can reuse some data and insights already.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Here’s some feedback from various users:
- Emily (OP Citizen House): this is very interesting! looks to me like I can use this to see the most connected people, who maybe also have the most influence... like vitalik and linda
- Griff (Citizen, Delegate): It’s a fantastic tool for coordination in the Citizen House. Seeing the shared connections can greatly support planning and partnerships, as well as aid in checking for collusion.
- Kevin Owocki (Citizen): seems like a nice way to get an at-a-glance view of the op political economy
- Divine Comedian (Citizen): Tried it out, visually it looks cool
- Luuk (OP Developer): That sounds great, we can add the graph to the Analytics page for sure. We’re also working on a second version of our website, which could have more sections about visualizations and maps

Also got accepted into Token Engineering the Superchain rounds, Web3 Grants Ecosystem Advancement, CollabTech Gitcoin rounds, got donations from 56 contributors.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
In collaboration with OSO, Passport XYZ's Humanity scores were used to better understand the likelihood of real humans that were interacting with projects over the last year. The goal was to determine which projects were driving spam/bot traffic versus which projects were driving real users to the Optimism ecosystem. 

These metrics and the analysis was used in the RPGF4 voting and review process, improving the understanding and (we believe) the outcome for voters by informing which projects were driving real humans, and organic users to the collective versus which were just bringing short term bots or spam users to the network (often low value and transient).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Our infrastructure and tooling has benefited the Badgeholder community the most, through our support of the RPGF rounds. Although we have made humanity proofs available via Attestations for nearly a year now on Optimism, the real value of this work has come from the inclusion and integration with the badgeholder experience (and collaboration with OSO) when reviewing and voting for projects to receive rewards.

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
In the past year, we deployed our stack on Base, resulting in the creation of nearly 2,000 DAOs on that chain. More recently, we’ve collaborated with Mode to develop their DAO with novel tokenomics aspects built into their governance model.

Besides that we've been working closely with relevant OP stakeholders like the Foundation and the grants council to develop a cutting edge cross-chain voting module that is desigend to be highly modular and adaptable. This allows other projects on Optimism to easily integrate with it or build on top of it. And thanks to Optimism’s ground-breaking work adopting EIP-4844 blobs into the OP blocks, we’ll be able to remove any trusted component and directly use Ethereum’s merkelized roots.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Protocols and their token holders that are build on Base are currently the ones who are benefitting the most from our free-to-use and open source governance tooling.
With Mode's launch we've been rapidly expanding already and we would like to include more projects on the superchain in the near future. 

Our unique value proposition is that the governance logic is programmed into plugins, making custom and granular governance designs easier, faster, and safer to build. It allows organizations to build multi-body, multi-process, and multichain governance, tailored to their unique needs. Plugins can be installed, upgraded, and uninstalled, allowing DAOs to evolve over time, onchain, via their governance process. As we expand to Optimism's Superchain, projects will instantly benefit from open-source plugins that have been battle-tested (with actual Lindy build on the plug-ins) and adopted by others.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We developed Pairwise for RF3, and introduced categories to make the impact measurement in the Retro Funding more organic and manageable.
In RF3, 185 users engaged, 27 badgeholders using their key
In RF4, we expanded into a community-wide experiment using pseudonymous voting with zk-tech. This allowed all stakeholders—badgeholders, token holders, recipients, and delegates—to participate freely without pressure and promote project discovery. Here you can find the final results, and our blog conclusions for more details on our outcomes.
The feedback from RF4 was very positive, leading to our invitation to build together with Optimism for RF5. For this round, we developed a star rating system, enabling participants to assign stars to projects before comparing them. This system grouped projects into tiers, significantly reducing the number of comparisons required.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main target when developing the product were badgeholders, who now can use Pairwise, to rank the Retro Funding projects in a fun way that promotes project discovery. However, the entire Optimism community, including delegates, token holders, and recipients, also gained through their participation in the Pairwise Retro Funding experiment, offering them the chance to discover impactful projects and bring more visibility to emerging initiatives. Projects benefited from increased exposure to potential users. Pairwise also sparks discussions  by comparing its results to official ones, fostering deeper insights and driving more meaningful participation and progress to decentralization.
To incentivize engagement, we distributed 4,000 OP as rewards giving a 100OP to 40 lucky winners, 10 on each stakeholder group participating in Pairwise.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Superfluid Protocol was used to distribute RPGF3 and RF4 grants, streaming over 32M OP to 900+ projects in the industry to date (RF4 streams are still ongoing).

The Superfluid Dashboard substantially improved the grants claim and management UX for recipients while allowing better funds distribution monitoring and management for the Optimism team. 

Recipients were also able to redirect streams to their team members ensuring they got paid in real-time as funding was being paid out by Optimism.  

You can read more about the improvements enabled by Superfluid here:
RPGF3 - https://medium.com/superfluid-blog/optimism-selects-superfluid-for-rpgf3-grants-streaming-612c37ecc89c
RF4 - https://medium.com/@superfluid_HQ/optimism-is-streaming-rf4-grants-with-superfluid-1835182bf18b

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Prior to the introduction of Superfluid Protocol in the retro funding process grant recipients had to claim their funds via direct interaction with Optimism's smart contracts, mostly by using the block explorer interface to make a contract call.

With the introduction of Superfluid recipients can see the total amount of OP awarded to them and the detailed timeline of the grant payout. They can also manage their incoming stream by redirecting it (or splitting it) to team members, third parties or DeFi apps in real time. You can read more about stream redirection and splitting here: https://help.superfluid.finance/en/articles/8907702-how-to-split-your-incoming-rpgf-grant

Superfluid also enabled smooth funds distribution, management and control for the Optimism team.

The entire community could benefit from transparent and easy to understand funding process, timeline and status (i.e. https://dune.com/0xkhmer/retropgf-3).

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
Strategic Oversight: Ensuring alignment between governance practices and the organization’s strategic goals.
Risk Management: Identifying, assessing, and managing risks to safeguard the organization’s assets and reputation.
Compliance: Ensuring adherence to legal, regulatory, and ethical standards.
Stakeholder Engagement: Facilitating communication and collaboration among stakeholders to foster transparency and trust.
Performance Monitoring: Evaluating organizational performance and governance effectiveness to promote continuous improvement.
Policy Development: Creating and maintaining governance policies that reflect best practices

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
nhanced Strategic Alignment: By actively engaging with leadership to align governance practices with strategic objectives, the function can ensure that decisions support long-term goals.

Robust Risk Management: Implementing comprehensive risk assessment frameworks can help identify potential issues early, enabling proactive measures that protect the organization and enhance resilience.

Strengthened Compliance Framework: Regularly reviewing and updating compliance policies ensures that the organization stays ahead of regulatory changes, minimizing the risk of non-compliance.

Effective Stakeholder Engagement: By fostering open communication channels with stakeholders, the function can build trust and encourage collaborative decision-making, which enhances overall governance.

Continuous Performance Monitoring: Establishing metrics to evaluate governance effectiveness allows for ongoing assessment and refinement of practices, ensuring they remain relevant and impactful.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Voting Participation:
   - Measuring the level of participation from token holders or voters in governance decisions.

2. Proposal Outcomes:
   - Analyzing the results of submitted proposals, including the level of support, opposition, and whether proposals are accepted or rejected.

3. Delegation Dynamics:
   - Tracking how voting power is delegated

4. Voting Power Distribution:
   - Monitoring the distribution of voting power among token holders

5. Proposal Submission Trends:
   - Measuring the frequency and content of submitted proposals

6. Token Economics Impact:
   - Analyzing the impact of governance decisions on the token economy, such as changes in token prices following major governance votes or accepted proposals.

7. Community Engagement:
   - Evaluating overall community engagement in governance, through discussions on forums, proposal feedback, and social media activity related to governance.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Governance Participants: Token holders who actively participate in voting and governance decision-making

2. Core Team & Developers.

3. Delegators and Voting Power Holders: Delegators or individuals holding significant voting power

4. Investors.

5. Community Members: Community members who are interested in transparency and accountability in governance

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
- Voter turnout: delegate participation as of last update
- Non-conformity: how many delegates have their "own" opinion when voting 
- Voting Bloc power over time: tracks the top100 or individual voting power over time
- Voting Cost: total gas cost across votes and average gas cost per delegate
- Inactive Delegates: who are they and how many votes they have
- Underrated Delegates: who have little voting power but has been consistently voting and has high-non-conformity score
- Statistics on Delegate Profiling: delegates who are self delegates vs those who have more than 1 delegators

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Professional Delegators such as a16z: to monitor performance of its delegates at OP Collective. With the dashboard that I created, they know which delegates are active and which are not contributing in governance. With the data in mind, it will facilitate liquid-delegations for their next cohort. 

OP Foundation: identify active OP delegates who are amongst the top 100 ones and conduct retro-reward for active participants accordingly. 

OP Collective Delegators: with the underrated delegate lists, they can support them by delegating OPs to these delegates and let them grow from bottom up.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We formulated a new **measure of decentralization** that applies to the Optimism Collective's two houses and offers scientifically grounded **guidance** for improvement. This metric is called _voting-bloc entropy_ (VBE, pronounced "vibe"). It is being used for measurements in three ways:

* In close consultation with Optimism, we developed Optimism-specific **software tools** for measuring VBE that are now being used by the Optimism Collective to understand voting behaviors and Optimism governance more broadly. 
* We have launched a **public dashboard** that presents VBE measurements across the DAO ecosystem and includes Optimism and other leading DAOs. See https://t.co/2BqeTJtkNI. (Optimism is #1 by a nose, i.e., currently shows the highest VBE.)
* VBE is proving an **important metric** for DAO decentralization study, as highlighted by its inclusion in, e.g., a recent Optimism Foundation Mission Request (#183).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Beneficiaries of the three forms of measurement above include:

1. The **Gov Team at Optimism** helped shape the software tools to benefit from their use in analyzing past and future voting rounds (e.g., RetroPGF rounds), conducting experiments, and improving governance practices.
2. The **broad DAO and DeFi community** can now assess DAO decentralization across the ecosystem at a glance on our VBE dashboard---and the **Optimism Collective** benefits from showcasing of its strong commitment to and comparatively high degree of decentralization.
3. **Teams performing research** for the Optimism Collective benefit from a rigorous metric for decentralization and supporting Optimism-specific software tools.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Gravity DAO supports Optimism by designing and implementing frameworks and standards for decentralization of governance, especially in conflict management, trust creation, and leadership.

We support multiple teams in the collective with their capacity to coordinate nonviolently and transform the energy from conflicting situations into fuel for growth. 

We have facilitated alternative dispute resolution and also evergreen educational content for individuals to continue their personal and professional development. 

Our created social infrastructure and tools are replicable, conceptually robust, minimal in governance overhead, and efficient in progressive decentralization. We consider our work to be long-term impactful for the collective because we are building good practices for common needs many groups face when building towards shared goals.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Gravity DAO is a public good project. We create content that is available and accessible to anyone interested, and that is forkable and adaptative to different scenarios. The people that have benefited the most from our infrastructure and tooling are the communities that get inspired by our frameworks, like Optimism, and the students, which we call Gravitons, who have taken our training and applied the set of gained skills in their life and in their participation on groups.

Our work equips contributors with the necessary skills to participate gracefully in Web3 governance, facilitating continued improvement, informed engagement, and desired types of interaction. We develop humans and processes to foster better coordination in groups. 

We are a small team, with 5 core contributors, and over 25 occasional ones. We want to increase the reach of our message and our capacity to grow, thinking that more people can benefit from our cutting-edge work on sociotechnical systems.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We wanted to understand the rounds scoring mechanism given the totals and numbers reported did not make sense as an applicant.

In our round analysis. We extracted the raw excel data and and transformed them into formats typically used in data science (machine learning).

In doing so we were able to create a visual representation of the scoring for the round. We uncovered (known) shortcomings of the platform and were able to provide the collective information in an easy to understand format.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?

I would say OP grants the lead Gonna.eth. After sharing my analysis, this led to a couple of initiatives that were since implemented in later rounds.

* Sharing anon scores against each rubic
* Making the individual reviewers scores public

My work was also referenced to support another members claim in the more topics ([Mission Request] Optimism Dominance in Yield-Bearing Assets (3 of 4) category) 

Which was super cool to see.

impactStatement.answer: The Retro Funding Review Tool enables application reviewers to ensure that all Retro Funding applications voted on by badge holders met eligibility criteria, prior to voting. The tool facilitated Retro Funding Round 4 & 5's application review process. Prior to CharmVerse, reviews were coordinated using complicated excel sheets where the core team spent countless hours in an error-prone process.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
All badge holder reviews for Retro Funding 4 and 5 were conducted on CharmVerse. The processes supported 416 applications with 271 applications approved. 46 Reviewers leveraged the platform to conduct their reviews. 

The tool saved the core team countless hours. It streamline the process and save time for the 46 reviewers. Finally, all applicants benefited from the result of a better run process with higher transparency and reduced bias and errors.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
CharmVerse powered the end to end grants process of the Grants Council, servicing a total of 1,171 applications across Season 5 and 6. The process includes application intake, Council evaluation, communication & notifications, and milestone tracking. 

Over the past 12 months, monthly active users ranged from ~1k to 4.4k. In Cycle 19, NPS from finalist was 9/10, exceeding target of 7/10, indicating high satisfaction levels among applicants with the grants process. 

"Special acknowledgment is due to the Charmverse team for their instrumental role in providing the necessary tools to facilitate the review process. Leveraging the rubric, workflow, and form tools for the first time, we achieved an impressive success rate of 97.2% out of 314 applications without errors and solved any issues on a 12-hour gap" - Gonna, Grants Council Lead

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
We work closely with the Grants Council and constantly evolve the platform to meet their specific needs and ensure great grantee experience in a timely manner. Both the Grants Council and grant applicants benefit from a transparent and efficient grants process. 

"We are delighted to announce that rubric comments are now integrated directly into your applications. Simply navigate to your application and check the sidebar to find scores for each rubric section, along with comments from reviewers. A huge thanks to the Charmverse team for implementing this feature so quickly." - Gonna, Grants Council Lead

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Syntra simplifies key governance tasks for OptimismDAO Delegates, improving efficiency and decision-making. It also helps with the onboarding of new participants lowering the barrier to entry.

"### **A Day in the Life of an OptimismDAO Delegate with Syntra**

- ***Efficient Proposal Creation***
	- *Delegates start their day by accessing a user-friendly dashboard and draft manager.*
	- *They can quickly draft proposals and use templates, cutting proposal creation time by 50%.*
- ***Informed Decision Making***
	- *Syntra provides an overview of updated resources, ensuring delegates have all necessary context at their disposal.*
	- *Integration with OptimismDAO's calendar helping delegates stay up to date with community calls, office hours and seasons timelines.*
- ***Cross-DAO Management***
	- *For delegates involved in multiple DAOs, Syntra provides a unified interface without the need of switching between platforms. This also lower the barrier to entry of external DAO actors*"

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Syntra contributed to Optimism Governance since its  **private alpha release in late August**  and  **public alpha release in early September**.

## Users:
### OptimismDAO delegates
-   **Newcomers**: Syntra lowered barriers to entry by simplifying proposal drafting, commenting, voting, and governance analysis.
-   **Professional teams**: It streamlined internal coordination with role-based access and tracking features.

As of October 8th, Syntra has:

-   **209 total logins**
-   **33 MAU**: 33 active Optimism sessions since Sept (Month to date). 
	- **Active**: at least 1 Draft created.
-   Users from  **5 different countries** to date.
-   Currently also being used by SEEDGov for drafting.

More information regarding activity is available in the [Google Drive link](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1TZWtb_Q67hwqBHNGpgT4V7HocAs1LNKT?usp=sharing).

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
RetroPGF Hub serves as the central infrastructure and governance tool for Retro Funding, a vital element of the Citizens' House. It empowers the Optimism community to actively participate in governance, explore comprehensive information, and stay well-informed about all aspects of Retro Funding.

Our platform offers detailed information on Retro Funding, including its foundational concepts, the historical context of each funding round, and in-depth insights into previously funded projects. This ensures governance participants have the knowledge they need to make informed decisions.

Additionally, we enhance community engagement by providing a space for feedback on builders' project ideas. This interaction fosters a continuous learning and improvement loop that benefits both the Optimism ecosystem and the builders contributing to it.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Several users, particularly new participants in the Retro Funding process, have greatly benefited from our infrastructure. Badgeholders, key in Retro Funding governance, are a primary group that benefits. Our platform enables them to easily participate, shape Retro Funding, and access critical project data, making research and discovery more efficient for governance participants within the Citizens' House.

Our platform is also recognized as a trusted source for Retro Funding details, with referrals from platforms like retrofunding.optimism.io (Optimism Official) and optimism.curiahub.xyz (CuriaLabs), directing users to project details for each funding round. This streamlines access to key information for governance participants.

Ultimately, our platform supports governance within the Optimism ecosystem, benefiting individual users and the broader structure. Our infrastructure continues to strengthen the Citizens' House, enhancing its ability to effectively of Retro Funding.

Since our solution is inherently free and easy to use, anyone can effortlessly create and track their on-chain communities on Remox. From project teams to community members, everyone benefits from our insights into treasury and governance, empowering them to make informed decisions and engage more actively in their ecosystems.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
EAS is foundational in Retro Funding and governance processes, providing structured, verifiable attestations that enhance accountability, trust, and accelerate decision-making.

In Retro Funding, EAS is used to:
- **Assign Unique Identifiers:** Provide unique IDs for all projects and organizations.
- **Manage Metadata:** Capture and update project/org info.
- **Record Applications:** Log project submissions to RF rounds.
- **Track Application Status:** Record approvals/rejections of applications.
- **Specify Rewards:** Detail reward amounts.

EAS also supports governance roles and contributions by representing citizenship status separately from voting rights, issuing voting badges for Retro Rounds, attesting to contributors in retro rounds, and recognizing those who held governance roles like Grants Council members.

View all schemas: https://docs.optimism.io/chain/identity/schemas

*Note:* Archived schemas have been utilized for RetroPGF3, Season 4, and Optimist Profiles.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
EAS impacts all participants involved in the Retro Funding experience.

**Governance Teams Overseeing Retro Funding**
OP grants/governance teams rely on EAS for transparent and verifiable decision-making, ensuring accountability throughout the Retro Funding process. EAS enables them to operate more efficiently, experiment readily, build trust, and scale governance.

**Retro Funding Participants**
RF project creators, reviewers, and other participants use EAS when creating profiles, submitting applications, approving or rejecting projects, and updating metadata. EAS ensures these interactions are structured and verifiable for each step of the RF experience.

**Governance Tooling & Analytic Providers**
These teams access EAS attestations to retrieve data, generate reports, and gain insights. These attestations make it easier to analyze RF activities and contribute to informed decision-making.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more
Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We conducted 2 researches that served as a reference for measuring participation in Governance:

Token House Participation and Incentives: Season 5 (Cycles 16-19), captures essential data on delegate participation and provides a condensed overview of governance during Season 5. It analyzes the Collective's evolution, highlighting significant findings such as a increase in mission proposals and a rise in active delegate participation, while noting a decline in mission approval rates, which may suggest a more rigorous selection process. 

Big Picture: The Grants Council, documents the evolution of the Grants Council, emphasizing its transition from a governance experiment to a vital structure within Optimism. This report details the Council's efforts to streamline grant distribution, enhance transparency, and improve fund management, offering a chronological and quantifiable perspective on its activities, structure, budget allocations, and results over the seasons.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The Token House Participation and Incentives served as a guide for the Foundation to determine the Retro Delegate Rewards for Season 5. While the Grants Council report was included as part of the govNERDs contribution path.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Many people don’t often think about whom they delegate their tokens to, or whether they have delegated them at all. Our frame reminds users of the delegation option, allowing them to review and choose a different delegate. 

Everything happens within the Farcaster app, with no need to go outside of it, making the process more convenient. The frame makes delegation easy and encourages people to think about governance.

The tool is in the form of a frame, which is a Farcaster invention. It’s essentially a link preview on steroids. Frames can include buttons and text fields that allow users to interact directly with them. A frame is basically a mini-app within Farcaster.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Citizens and delegates active on Farcaster have benefited the most from the Optimism Delegate Frame. 

Delegates can share pre-filled frames with their information, making it easy for users to delegate to them with just a few clicks. This system allows delegates to promote themselves while reminding citizens to check their current delegate and switch if they choose. 

Since these frames are shared publicly on Farcaster, they help raise awareness about Optimism governance and encourage more users to engage with the delegation process.

impactStatement.answer:
The Developer Advisory Board (DAB) was reelected in Season 6 with a provisional budget of 90,000 OP. [Our charter can be found in the initial budget proposal](https://gov.optimism.io/t/zach-obront-developer-advisory-board-operating-budget/8141), and includes supporting the Optimism ecosystem as follows:

1. Help to ensure the safety of protocol upgrades. We do this by both (a) explicitly approving upgrades before they are allowed to move to a vote and (b) providing plain English summaries of all protocol upgrades to educate other voters.

2. Support the Grants Council by providing detailed technical feedback on all Mission Requests, Mission Applications, and grant milestones.

3. Bring an additional technical perspective to thinking about the vision of the OP ecosystem and what needs to happen to get there.

More details can be found in our [Internal Operating Procedures](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-s6-internal-operating-procedures/8558).

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
- Provided detailed feedback on [139 mission requests](https://wbnns.notion.site/Developer-Advisory-Board-Impact-11acf4706b47808f8421c409b4c102c6?pvs=4) thus far (105 of which are within the round eligibility period), to aid in evaluation by the Grants Council. The GC Lead has provided an NPS score of 10/10 based on the value of our contributions.
- Reviewed the Granite Hardfork, formally approved it, and prepared an [extensive and comprehensive non-technical summary](https://gov.optimism.io/t/upgrade-proposal-10-granite-network-upgrade/8733/21) to support other voters.
- Provided feedback to the Foundation on important projects such as the Decentralization Roadmap and long term Product Vision.
- Conducted multiple community calls throughout Season 6, [creating an open forum](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-feedback-ideas-thread/8580) to get feedback and ideas from the community.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more
Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
EVM Explorer's analytics work provides valuable insights into the influence of smart contract behavior on governance processes, enhancing transparency and understanding of the impact of smart contracts on Optimism Governance.

Smart Contract Performance: Analyzing the performance and usage of smart contracts within the Optimism network to understand their impact on governance processes. This includes tracking metrics such as the number of interactions with specific contracts, the frequency of transactions, and the distribution of contract usage across different governance-related functions.

Governance-relevant Token Balances: Tracking and analyzing token balances that are relevant to governance, such as voting tokens or tokens used for delegating authority. This analysis sheds light on the distribution of voting power, governance-related events, and stakeholder engagement in governance decision-making.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The analytics work by EVM Explorer on smart contract behavior in Optimism Governance benefits various ecosystem stakeholders. Active governance participants gain insights into smart contract performance and token balances, aiding informed decision-making and effective participation. Governance teams leverage detailed analytics to assess governance mechanisms, identify areas for enhancement, and tailor strategies. Developers benefit from understanding user interactions with contracts, leading to improved contract efficiency. Token projects find value in analytics on token balances and distribution for assessing engagement and governance mechanisms. Researchers benefit from comprehensive analytics, deepening insights into governance processes and contributing to the governance community. Overall, EVM Explorer's analytics enhance transparency, understanding, and efficiency in Optimism Governance, benefiting stakeholders across the ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer: Our analytics work provides insights into both treasury and governance data within Optimism. On the treasury side, we track historical treasury value, holdings, and transactions and provide month-over-month comparisons to help visualize trends. For governance, we display all proposals categorized by their status and offer a clear view of active voters. impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: Our analytics work has benefited on-chain communities across EVM chains, particularly within the Superchain ecosystem, including Optimism, Base, and Celo. Since our solution is inherently free and easy to use, anyone can effortlessly create and track their on-chain communities on Remox. From project teams to community members, everyone benefits from our insights into treasury and governance, empowering them to make informed decisions and engage more actively in their ecosystems.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?

- Data transparency within the Collective: The Optimism Collective is one of the largest DAOs, with new aretfacts being released continuously. This includes information on committees & councils, list of important initiatives, links to governance, list of voters, etc. Through EIP-4824, we have created an onchain source of truth on the Optimism Collective. subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Code of Conduct Council has significantly contributed to improving the enforcement of governance standards within Optimism. By taking over the processing of Code of Conduct violation reports, the Council has streamlined enforcement, removing the burden from Token House delegates and allowing them to focus on higher-level governance matters. During Season 5, no Code of Conduct issues were escalated to the Token House, despite multiple submissions occurring during this period. 
In Season 5, the Council implemented clear processes for handling disputes, including a transparent reporting system that publishes enforcement decisions. Also, confirming and denying grant clawback requests from the grants council smooth lined the process in how teams that hadn’t met their milestones would be treated. Further, initiatives like GravityDAO’s conflict resolution training demonstrated the Council’s commitment to preventative measures, reducing the likelihood of violations in the first place.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Council helped foster a more accessible and fair enforcement process that clearly laid out the framework and operations around possible community violations. As this was the first cohort involved in the Code of Conduct, all members had to also reflect not only on the duties initially assigned by the original proposal, but also the potential for improvement and limitations of the system established and its Internal Operating Procedures.
The impact and want for something like this was proven apparent by the Council’s reapproval, this time with a new budget of up to 6000 OP per member (vs 3000 OP in S5). This shift has improved governance efficiency, ensuring timely and impartial enforcement of community standards. The introduction of preventative measures, such as conflict resolution training, further supports long-term community well-being. Through these, the Council has played a crucial role in maintaining Optimism’s integrity and promoting sustainable governance practices.

impactStatement.answer: The primary beneficiaries of our project are Delegates and Citizens involved in Optimism Governance. They benefit from instant access to active proposals directly in their social feeds, allowing them to stay informed and ensure they don’t miss important votes.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?

By condensing all of this information into 1 hour and by bringing experts into the discussion, Delegates and Citizens are able to participate more effectively across every area of Optimism Governance.

Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We have created a comprehensive analysis of Optimism Badgeholder's onchain activity vs a control group of active non-Badgeholders. In particular, we looked at transaction activity across chains, involvement in social apps (Farcaster, Lens, Friendtech), participation in other DAOs (Arbitrum, Uniswap, ENS) and the deployment of smart contracts and NFTs. 

Something to note: although it is true that not all citizens use their Badgeholder address for other onchain activity, we found that a significant amount did and we discuss the implications of this constraint in the report.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation. This work was requested directly by the Foundation in order to get a better understanding of Optimism Badgeholders vs “normal” Ethereum users. In their own words: “In order to confidently expand the Citizenry, we need to have a baseline understanding of the current Badgeholder group. Our goal is to get a better understanding of the Badgeholder group based on their onchain activity compared with the onchain activity of other active Optimism/Ethereum users.”

In addition, the entire Optimism Collective has benefitted from the transparency provided by this publicly available work. It's open source nature sets the stage for others to conduct further research and expand upon our results.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer: Our analytics work provides insights into both treasury and governance data within Optimism. On the treasury side, we track historical treasury value, holdings, and transactions and provide month-over-month comparisons to help visualize trends. For governance, we display all proposals categorized by their status and offer a clear view of active voters. This allows users to stay informed about the overall health of Optimism’s governance and financial ecosystem in an easy-to-understand way, ensuring transparency and helping drive informed decision-making.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: Our analytics work has benefited on-chain communities across EVM chains, particularly within the Superchain ecosystem, including Optimism, Base, and Celo. Since our solution is inherently free and easy to use, anyone can effortlessly create and track their on-chain communities on Remox. From project teams to community members, everyone benefits from our insights into treasury and governance, empowering them to make informed decisions and engage more actively in their ecosystems.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Our analysis measures the participation and behavior of Badgeholders in the Superchain ecosystem, specifically focusing on their transaction activities across networks like OP Mainnet, Base, Zora, and Mode. It also examines their engagement in decentralized applications (DEXs), token transfers, and social platforms like Farcaster. 

A key insight is the relatively low activity level of Badgeholders compared to Non-Badgeholders, particularly in areas like DEX trading and smart contract deployment. Additionally, the analysis tracks how Badgeholders' preferences for Ethereum transactions and limited cross-chain activity impact their overall engagement with Optimism's governance processes. 

This helps identify where governance structures may need to be adjusted to include better and activate Badgeholders, ensuring their participation grows alongside the broader ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Collective has benefitted most from this analysis, gaining valuable insights into Badgeholder behavior that inform strategies to increase engagement. For example, understanding that Badgeholders are more active on Ethereum but less engaged with smart contract deployment helps the Collective target these users with specific governance initiatives. 

Furthermore, the findings around Farcaster connections show the importance of social engagement within this group, which can shape future governance outreach and participation efforts. The insights have also helped governance teams refine their strategies for promoting cross-chain activity and diversifying user engagement. This research will also guide the future selection of new Badgeholders for the Citizen House by identifying gaps and ensuring the House becomes more inclusive and representative of the entire user profile within the Collective, promoting a well-rounded governance structure.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We developed Pairwise for RF3, and introduced categories to make the impact measurement in the Retro Funding more organic and manageable.
In RF3, 185 users engaged, 27 badgeholders using their key
In RF4, we expanded into a community-wide experiment using pseudonymous voting with zk-tech. This allowed all stakeholders—badgeholders, token holders, recipients, and delegates—to participate freely without pressure and promote project discovery. Here you can find the final results, and our blog conclusions for more details on our outcomes.
The feedback from RF4 was very positive, leading to our invitation to build together with Optimism for RF5. For this round, we developed a star rating system, enabling participants to assign stars to projects before comparing them. This system grouped projects into tiers, significantly reducing the number of comparisons required.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main target when developing the product were badgeholders, who now can use Pairwise, to rank the Retro Funding projects in a fun way that promotes project discovery. However, the entire Optimism community, including delegates, token holders, and recipients, also gained through their participation in the Pairwise Retro Funding experiment, offering them the chance to discover impactful projects and bring more visibility to emerging initiatives. Projects benefited from increased exposure to potential users. Pairwise also sparks discussions  by comparing its results to official ones, fostering deeper insights and driving more meaningful participation and progress to decentralization.
To incentivize engagement, we distributed 4,000 OP as rewards giving a 100OP to 40 lucky winners, 10 on each stakeholder group participating in Pairwise.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more
Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We conducted 2 researches that served as a reference for measuring participation in Governance:

Token House Participation and Incentives: Season 5 (Cycles 16-19), captures essential data on delegate participation and provides a condensed overview of governance during Season 5. It analyzes the Collective's evolution, highlighting significant findings such as a increase in mission proposals and a rise in active delegate participation, while noting a decline in mission approval rates, which may suggest a more rigorous selection process. 

Big Picture: The Grants Council, documents the evolution of the Grants Council, emphasizing its transition from a governance experiment to a vital structure within Optimism. This report details the Council's efforts to streamline grant distribution, enhance transparency, and improve fund management, offering a chronological and quantifiable perspective on its activities, structure, budget allocations, and results over the seasons.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The Token House Participation and Incentives served as a guide for the Foundation to determine the Retro Delegate Rewards for Season 5. While the Grants Council report was included as part of the govNERDs contribution path.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Delegates are the cornerstone of Optimism's governance system. Active and well-informed delegates lead to resilient and sound governance. However, delegates need to process a lot of information and often find it challenging to stay up-to-date. We are humans after all.

To help delegates stay active and well-informed, our team launched Tribuni—a free Telegram mini-app built exclusively for delegates. Tribuni sends quality AI-generated proposal summaries, vote reminders, and OP forum activity digests directly via Telegram. This ensures that delegates never miss a vote or an important discussion within the OP ecosystem, as long as they're connected to Telegram.

impactStatement.answer:
People managing 28 OP delegate profiles use Tribuni.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
In collaboration with OSO, Passport XYZ's Humanity scores were used to better understand the likelihood of real humans that were interacting with projects over the last year. The goal was to determine which projects were driving spam/bot traffic versus which projects were driving real users to the Optimism ecosystem. 

These metrics and the analysis was used in the RPGF4 voting and review process, improving the understanding and (we believe) the outcome for voters by informing which projects were driving real humans, and organic users to the collective versus which were just bringing short term bots or spam users to the network (often low value and transient).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Our infrastructure and tooling has benefited the Badgeholder community the most, through our support of the RPGF rounds. Although we have made humanity proofs available via Attestations for nearly a year now on Optimism, the real value of this work has come from the inclusion and integration with the badgeholder experience (and collaboration with OSO) when reviewing and voting for projects to receive rewards.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We measure various aspects of the Optimism Token House to capture how susceptible it is to multiple risk factors we identify. These risk factors are (RF1) voter apathy, (RF2) high governance token liquidity, (RF3) large treasury, (RF4) inadequate configuration, (RF5) centralization, and (RF6) code uncertainties. For each of these risk factors, we identify multiple empirical measures that let us assess how vulnerable a DAO is. Note that we do this analysis not only for the Optimism Token House but also for another 25 DAOs in the Ethereum ecosystem.
 
We further created a data set of attacks on DAOs in the past, but none are directly related to Optimism Governance.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Our analytical work benefits two groups. The first group is protocols that use a DAO for their governance. They can use the dataset of attacks, as well as the empirical measures we identify to assess the vulnerability of their DAO and react if needed. The same holds for those protocols that want to switch to DAO governance, which can make some of these assessments before they make the switch.
 
Additionally, it benefits those who have a stake in the DAO (i.e., those who hold the token) to assess the vulnerability of the DAO.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer: Our analytics work provides insights into both treasury and governance data within Optimism. On the treasury side, we track historical treasury value, holdings, and transactions and provide month-over-month comparisons to help visualize trends. For governance, we display all proposals categorized by their status and offer a clear view of active voters. This allows users to stay informed about the overall health of Optimism’s governance and financial ecosystem in an easy-to-understand way, ensuring transparency and helping drive informed decision-making.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: Our analytics work has benefited on-chain communities across EVM chains, particularly within the Superchain ecosystem, including Optimism, Base, and Celo. Since our solution is inherently free and easy to use, anyone can effortlessly create and track their on-chain communities on Remox. From project teams to community members, everyone benefits from our insights into treasury and governance, empowering them to make informed decisions and engage more actively in their ecosystems.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We have created a comprehensive analysis of Optimism Badgeholder's onchain activity vs a control group of active non-Badgeholders. In particular, we looked at transaction activity across chains, involvement in social apps (Farcaster, Lens, Friendtech), participation in other DAOs (Arbitrum, Uniswap, ENS) and the deployment of smart contracts and NFTs. 

Something to note: although it is true that not all citizens use their Badgeholder address for other onchain activity, we found that a significant amount did and we discuss the implications of this constraint in the report.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation. This work was requested directly by the Foundation in order to get a better understanding of Optimism Badgeholders vs “normal” Ethereum users. In their own words: “In order to confidently expand the Citizenry, we need to have a baseline understanding of the current Badgeholder group. Our goal is to get a better understanding of the Badgeholder group based on their onchain activity compared with the onchain activity of other active Optimism/Ethereum users.”

In addition, the entire Optimism Collective has benefitted from the transparency provided by this publicly available work. It's open source nature sets the stage for others to conduct further research and expand upon our results.

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
There have been 23 community governance calls in this impact period. In addition, we have had two "speed dating" sessions, mission request workshops, and other AMAs.

The calls have been a key place to discuss *everything* that has happened in governance during that time, and calls usually get 40-50 key participants from Optimism Governance.

A small sampling of topics/guests in this impact period:
* Jing presenting and Q&A on the Superchain vision
* Base Governance team Rowan & Saemi discussing Base's participation
* Ben Jones presenting Blockspace Charters
* Kelvin Fitchner Granite Network Upgrade AMA
* Justine with a Season 6 Governance AMA
* Launamu preseting Impact Metrics Garden
* PaperImperium discussing a proposal on accelerated governance decentralization
* Roberto Bayardo (Base) presenting Fjord/Ecotone upgrades
* Emily presenting Guest Voter Participation
* Jonas presenting multiple Retro Funding rounds

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
These calls are the critical space for all governance participants to become informed, ask questions, and discuss every current issue across the Token House and the Citizen's House.

By condensing all of this information into 1 hour and by bringing experts into the discussion, Delegates and Citizens are able to participate more effectively across every area of Optimism Governance.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Delegates are the cornerstone of Optimism's governance system. Active and well-informed delegates lead to resilient and sound governance. However, delegates need to process a lot of information and often find it challenging to stay up-to-date. We are humans after all.

To help delegates stay active and well-informed, our team launched Tribuni—a free Telegram mini-app built exclusively for delegates. Tribuni sends quality AI-generated proposal summaries, vote reminders, and OP forum activity digests directly via Telegram. This ensures that delegates never miss a vote or an important discussion within the OP ecosystem, as long as they're connected to Telegram.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Lighthouse native mobile app makes it easy for Citizens and Delegates to participate in Optimism governance. We built support for Optimism's custom Governor contract, which enabled us to add multiple powerful new features:

1. We've added real time push notifications of new proposal and voting activity. 

2. We've added the ability to vote on proposals, on-chain, natively from within the Lighthouse app. 

3. We also pulled in on-chain comments and displayed them within the app, to surface community sentiment around proposals for users.

4. Our interactive Farcaster Frames integration enables on-chain proposals and comments to be shared, further increasing awareness and participation in the social media space.

This all works together to provide a powerful and feature-complete alternative client for users who wish to vote on the go.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Token holders, delegates and followers benefit by Optimism being on Lighthouse. Even users who do not hold Optimism tokens are able to follow core Optimism proposal activity, making Optimism governance more accessible throughout the ecosystem.
