subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We built this site in response to forum feedback, where many community members shared feeling overwhelmed by the constantly evolving nature of Optimism governance, in particular the many novel experiments around grant programs.

While rapid iteration is good for innovation (yay!), it also made it more challenging to stay up-to-date without first having to "navigate a maze of forum posts". We made it easy to access all deadlines and changes to programs in one place.

This has been well received: In the period between Oct 2023 and Sept 2024, there have been 2.9K outbound link clicks from our site to the Charmverse Grants Council page, 1.1K clicks to the Foundation Mission Requests pages on GitHub, and 605 clicks to forum posts on Retro Funding Rounds.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Our site has primarily been useful as tool for supporting those involved in grants processes, including the Grants Council, Retro Funding Rounds and (Foundation) Mission Requests.

The subscribers of our newsletter where we used to share weekly updates, before then focusing primarily on the website, include employees from OP Labs, OpenZeppelin and Wakeup Labs. 

The teams behind grantee projects such as OpenZeppelin are those who likely benefited most from our overview of the current status of grant programs, upcoming deadlines, our grants calendar, and the changelog. They otherwise would have had a much higher workload by having to keep track of this information across a number of different channels (GitHub, Grants Council Charmverse page, Forum, ...)

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Each Badgeholder session has had a different focus given that the needs are matched according to the stage of RetroRounds and the current experiments being carried out:

1. Workshops on the creation of lists for 3 different categories prior to RetroRound3. I designed and ran the workshops in a couple of them with the support of 2 other Badgeholders.
2. Istanbul Meetup @ Onchain Summit where we gathered to 1) connect, 2) explore thoughts on lists and voting, 3) learn about projects such as Pairwise. Secured a place with the OP team, created merch, and coordinated with Badgeholders attending DevConnect. 
3. Badgies Workshopping @ Eth Denver: Coordinated the event, contacted the presenting teams, and led the session.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Each session has led to different improvements in the process and experiments of RetroRounds. 
For the first two, the outcomes are described above. 

For the 3 Session, here is some additional information:

In this session the following teams presented and received feedback from Badgeholders and the Foundation:
1. EZKL - https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz/
2. Buidl Guild - Metrics Based Voting
3. Agora 
4. Pairwise
5. EasyRPGF

 This session particularly informed changes in the design of voting for Round 4, the release of EZKL's proving system for Retro3 results, among other things.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Gitcoin developed the voting interfaces for Retrofunding 4 & Retrofunding 5, which were used by badgeholders to allocate funds during those rounds.

For RF4, we worked closely with Open Source Observer and Optimism to implement new metrics-based discovery, selection, and weighting. Our solution allowed users to filter and evaluate projects based on various impact metrics. 

For both RF 4 & RF5, we created a user-friendly interface for governance participants to allocate their votes. 

These tools are primarily used within Optimism Governance to support the Retroactive Public Goods Funding process, which is a crucial part of Optimism's governance model. They aim to make the process of discovering, evaluating, and voting for projects more efficient, transparent, and user-friendly for governance participants.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The direct benefits are the Optimism badgeholders and recipients of Retrofunding. During RF4, 108 out of 133 badgeholders participated. $10M OP tokens were allocated to 207 projects. 

Though RF5 is still ongoing at the time of this application, participation is high. Badgeholders are expected to allocate between 2-8m OP tokens to up to 89 projects.

The team has also integrated these features into EasyRetroPGF.xyz, which makes them available to a wider range of users involved in Optimism's governance processes. The SUNNYS Awards have also been built on this same technology!

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
The numbaNERDs Program measures several key aspects of Optimism Governance:

Grant Utilization: Tracking how funds are used by recipients and whether milestones are met, ensuring proper fund allocation.

Grants Misuse: Validating reports of misuse through the grants misuse reporting policy, ensuring accountability and corrective actions.

Contributor Validation: Ensuring data accuracy by having numbaNERDs validate key reports for governance decisions.

Governance Accountability: Monitoring protocol adherence to governance rules and enforcing consequences for violations.

Data Infrastructure: Building analytics infrastructure for various protocols, initially on OP Mainnet, and later expanding to early Superchain members.

These analytics strengthen transparency, accountability, and decision-making across Optimism’s governance.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The numbaNERDs Program has significantly advanced governance-related analytics, data infrastructure, and transparency within the Optimism ecosystem, fostering growth and enabling informed decision-making. With 95 bounties completed and 3 grants misuse reports validated by numbaNERDs, the collective contributions of the numbaNERDs community have propelled Optimism's data infrastructure to excel beyond any other protocol in the blockchain ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
**Discord Praise Bot:**

Allows users to praise one another within their community for contributions, which are then stored and minted as on-chain attestations on Optimism Network.

Facilitates community recognition and builds trust through transparent records of contributions.
Since Oct 1st, 2023 to Sep 18th, 2024, We had a total of 642 Praises. Each one a statement of gratitude, as well as reputational data. 

200+ Active users 



**Praise on Farcaster:**

Integrates Praise’s attestation capabilities onto Farcaster. Users can tag @givepraise to publicly appreciate other Farcaster accounts.

Farcaster Frame Praise Attestations lowers the barrier to entry for creating user reputation, contributing to proof of uniqueness and reputation scores across the Web3 ecosystem.

236 attestations minted since the launch on Praise Farcaster bot (within 2 weeks)

76 Unique users minted attestations

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
**Active Participants in Optimism Governance:**

Delegates & Badgeholders:

Can easily show gratitude
Can help community members build onchain reputation. 

Engaged Community Members:
Gain visibility and reputation through peer recognition.
Boosts motivation to participate in governance activities.
Better vibes

**Individuals Verifying Reputations and Identities:**

Onchain Attestations:
Provide a transparent and verifiable record of contributions.
Aid in assessing community members' reputations.

Trust Building:
Help users make informed decisions within governance.
Lower the barrier to entry for new contributors seeking to build trust.

Overall Impact:
Simplified the process of acknowledging contributions and verifying reputations.
Strengthened engagement and collaboration within the Optimism governance ecosystem.

They aim to make the process of discovering, evaluating, and voting for projects more efficient, transparent, and user-friendly for governance participants.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The direct benefits are the Optimism badgeholders and recipients of Retrofunding. During RF4, 108 out of 133 badgeholders participated. $10M OP tokens were allocated to 207 projects. 

Though RF5 is still ongoing at the time of this application, participation is high. Badgeholders are expected to allocate between 2-8m OP tokens to up to 89 projects.

The team has also integrated these features into EasyRetroPGF.xyz, which makes them available to a wider range of users involved in Optimism's governance processes. The SUNNYS Awards have also been built on this same technology!

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Optimystics Tools has supported Optimism Governance by providing and maintaining essential infrastructure for decentralized decision-making over the past year:

1. Initial Toolset: Our core tools have facilitated weekly Optimism Fractal events, enabling consistent governance experimentation and community building.

2. Respect Infrastructure: We've maintained and upgraded the system for distributing Respect tokens, enabling a decentralized distribution amongst leading builders and governance enthusiasts.

3. Council Support: Our tools have enabled the weekly formation and operation of the Optimism Fractal council, demonstrating scalable governance models and creating a well-organized governance body for the Collective.

This consistent infrastructure has allowed for the release of next-generation tools like ORDAO, Fractalgram, and the Respect Games app. It’s enabled a community-driven effort with multiple development teams contributing to a growing toolkit of fractal governance tooling

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Builders, leaders, delegates, and other key stakeholders in the Collective have used our tools at Optimism Fractal events to earn Respect and contribute to decentralized decision-making experiments.

2. Our open-source infrastructure has served as a foundation for further governance innovations on Optimism, empowering researchers and developers interested in decentralized governance.

3. Our tools have provided models and insights that could enhance various governance processes, including the Token House, Citizens' House, RetroFunding, and the Anti-Capture Commission.

4. Other groups like the ZAO Fractal have adopted processes to engage, govern, and grow their communities on the Superchain. 

Our tools have created a vibrant testbed for governance innovations, benefiting anyone interested in exploring and contributing to decentralized decision-making processes on Optimism, and providing valuable data and experiences that can inform the evolution of the Collective's governance.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
RetroList, a project discovery platform for OP Retro Funding, significantly supports Optimism governance by providing detailed analytics and accessible data across Retro Funding rounds 3 to 6.

RetroList also offers detailed analytics for each round, including:
- Project reward distribution across different reward groups
- Project reward distribution by category
- Public crowdsourcing lists for RetroPGF 3
- Metrics distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Open-source vs. closed-source project distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Project reward breakdown by impact metrics for Retro Funding 4

Additionally, RetroList has provided an API that enables direct data queries by other projects like DeVouch and Impact Garden.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Every stakeholder in the Retro Funding process benefits from RetroList, including:
- Any user can discover Retro Funding projects and get inspiration to build on the Superchain.
- Project owners have a UI to check if their project has gone through correctly.
- Badgeholders, delegates, and the OP Foundation have access to the RetroList analytics, which has an impact on badgeholders' voting decisions and the design of future Retro Funding rounds.
- Ecosystem projects have access to the API for querying project data within a few days after the sign-up period and maintain a stable schema.

The RetroList API has been used internally by the DeVouch and Impact Garden projects.

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer: The mandate of govNERDs was to enhance governance accessibility by taking on key responsibilities that streamline the proposal process, such as guiding proposals through feedback, approval, and voting stages. We facilitated collaboration among proposers, ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods, and maintained onboarding hubs for both Token House and Citizens' House. Our work aimed to ensure high-quality engagement in the governance forum while reducing the administrative burden on the Optimism Foundation, thus enabling a smoother and more inclusive governance process.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During Season 5, govNERDs successfully reduced the Foundation’s workload by taking over key governance responsibilities. We managed Voting Cycle Roundups, drafted vote copy, and handled announcements for voting and veto cycles, making the governance process more efficient. govNERDs also ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods during the first season of Citizen’s House governance and maintained the Token House and Citizens’ House Onboarding Hubs. Additionally, our efforts in monitoring the forum, answering community questions, and providing feedback in retrospectives significantly enhanced delegate and Citizen experiences. This performance exceeded our mandate by streamlining operations and setting the stage for an open contribution path in Season 6.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Our analysis measures the participation and behavior of Badgeholders in the Superchain ecosystem, specifically focusing on their transaction activities across networks like OP Mainnet, Base, Zora, and Mode. It also examines their engagement in decentralized applications (DEXs), token transfers, and social platforms like Farcaster. 

A key insight is the relatively low activity level of Badgeholders compared to Non-Badgeholders, particularly in areas like DEX trading and smart contract deployment. Additionally, the analysis tracks how Badgeholders' preferences for Ethereum transactions and limited cross-chain activity impact their overall engagement with Optimism's governance processes. 

This helps identify where governance structures may need to be adjusted to include better and activate Badgeholders, ensuring their participation grows alongside the broader ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Collective has benefitted most from this analysis, gaining valuable insights into Badgeholder behavior that inform strategies to increase engagement. For example, understanding that Badgeholders are more active on Ethereum but less engaged with smart contract deployment helps the Collective target these users with specific governance initiatives. 

Furthermore, the findings around Farcaster connections show the importance of social engagement within this group, which can shape future governance outreach and participation efforts. The insights have also helped governance teams refine their strategies for promoting cross-chain activity and diversifying user engagement. This research will also guide the future selection of new Badgeholders for the Citizen House by identifying gaps and ensuring the House becomes more inclusive and representative of the entire user profile within the Collective, promoting a well-rounded governance structure.

impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Developer Advisory Board (DAB) was reelected in Season 6. [Our charter can be found in the initial budget proposal](https://gov.optimism.io/t/zach-obront-developer-advisory-board-operating-budget/8141), and includes supporting the Optimism ecosystem as follows:

1. Help to ensure the safety of protocol upgrades. We do this by both (a) explicitly approving upgrades before they are allowed to move to a vote and (b) providing plain English summaries of all protocol upgrades to educate other voters.

2. Support the Grants Council by providing detailed technical feedback on all Mission Requests, Mission Applications, and grant milestones.

3. Bring an additional technical perspective to thinking about the vision of the OP ecosystem and what needs to happen to get there.

More details can be found in our [Internal Operating Procedures](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-s6-internal-operating-procedures/8558).

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
- Provided detailed feedback on [139 mission requests](https://wbnns.notion.site/Developer-Advisory-Board-Impact-11acf4706b47808f8421c409b4c102c6?pvs=4) thus far (105 of which are within the round eligibility period), to aid in evaluation by the Grants Council. The GC Lead has provided an NPS score of 10/10 based on the value of our contributions.
- Reviewed the Granite Hardfork, formally approved it, and prepared an [extensive and comprehensive non-technical summary](https://gov.optimism.io/t/upgrade-proposal-10-granite-network-upgrade/8733/21) to support other voters.
- Provided feedback to the Foundation on important projects such as the Decentralization Roadmap and long term Product Vision.
- Conducted multiple community calls throughout Season 6, [creating an open forum](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-feedback-ideas-thread/8580) to get feedback and ideas from the community.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Token House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering high-context feedback from engaged community members during the design phase, rather than after designs are finalized. By consulting the Foundation on early-stage drafts, we ensure that input from top delegates and governance leads directly shapes decisions as they are being developed. CFC members provided feedback on any drafts shared by the Optimism Foundation. This approach marks a significant first step toward deeper community involvement in the governance design process, aligning with the long-term goal of increased community ownership. 

More details can be found here:
- Introducing the Collective Feedback Commission:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863
- The Path to Open Metagovernance
https://gov.optimism.io/t/the-path-to-open-metagovernance/7728

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The CFC Token House achieved its mandate by providing high-context feedback on 15 documents during Season 6, aligning with the Optimism Foundation's goal of reducing dependency on the Foundation in governance design. 

Key impacts include:
- Eliminated Trust Tiers from Season 6 grant applications.
- Implemented a 72-hour response SLA for the Developer Advisory Board (DAB).
- Clarified retro reward eligibility and expanded “stakeholders” scope.
- Strengthened Chain Delegation Program with clearer criteria.
- Refined the Superchain strategy, leading to the Vision AMA.

Based on this success, the Commission will continue into its next iteration. More details here:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/collective-feedback-commission-pilot-retrospective/8970

Reward split:
The rewards split for CFC members was based on the number of reviews each completed.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Ptp8e3G5IfJi62aStBjOvNoJnH69glley_qWa3L6j-0/edit?usp=sharing

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Badgeholder votes are private. This allows voters to express their true preferences without fear of retaliation, coercion, or pressure from others. It makes it difficult to execute vote buying, and encourages honest participation. It doesn't protect against the vote counter cheating.

Even though the allocation algorithm is public (and we can check that it accurately codifies forum promises), we can’t run a check without the input data. In the worst case, we can’t guarantee that the provided allocation algorithm was even used or that all votes were counted.

We made this process transparent with zero-knowledge (ZK) proof that legitimate votes were counted and that the allocation algorithm was run as intended, keeping the votes themselves private. Using EZKL, we were able to compile the Python allocation code into a circuit, and provide a proof anyone can verify at https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz (see https://blog.ezkl.xyz/post/zkrpgf/ for more details).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The Retroactive Public Goods Funding process ideally improves with each round via governance feedback. We cryptographically audited Round 3 in a replicable way, providing a cryptographic proof any stakeholder can verify in a browser. This paves the way for an end-to-end automated process with private voting, checks and balances on the allocation algorithm, and smart contract enabled allocation delivery

For stakeholders, this cryptographic audit means many things:
- For badgeholders, your vote was fairly counted
- For recipients, your allocation was fairly calculated
- For everyone else, the results actually correspond with Optimism governance — governance at work!

Blockchains have both social consensus (which fork is the main one, which client should be run, etc.) and computational consensus. By verifying the RetroPGF results, everyone helps solidify the social consensus around the legitimacy of the vote. You are an election observer, contributing to a successful audit.

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was created to prevent capture of the Token House by any single tokenholder or group, including protocols and OP Chains. It represents high-impact individual delegates and acts as a communication bridge between the Token House and Citizens' House, addressing imbalances in power and maintaining governance integrity.

Relevant Documentation:
- Anticapture Commission Charter
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission/6889
- Anticapture Commission Communication Thread
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501
- Season 5 Retrospective
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-retrospective-season-5/8108
- Internal Operating Procedures
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-internal-operating-procedures/7348

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) fulfilled its Season 5 mandate by representing individual delegates and preventing capture of the Token House by any entity. It developed Internal Operating Procedures (IOP), defining voting protocols, communication methods, and reporting processes. The ACC held regular Office Hours to maintain community engagement, though no reports to the Citizens' House were required.

Key Impacts:
- Increased votable supply from 72.6M to 90M OP with a 10M OP delegation.
- 165 of 269 delegate approvals from ACC members during key cycles.
- Initiated discussions leading to on-chain governor upgrades.

Reward Split: 
A point system was used for the reward split, considering attendance at office hours, internal meetings, and voting on proposals not included in retro rewards with 20% allocated to the Lead due to the role’s extra responsibilities.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_4p_C7NQ-UjVXH5O0HXoSYIWKwJeN3JQX3NZZLLMTlc/edit?usp=sharing

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Impact Garden is used to gather standardized information on a project's impact to the Optimism Collective beyond that being self reported by applicants. The information collected is linked to the reputation of the person providing the testimonial enabling advanced weighting by the consumer of the data. Higher reputation in the Collective, can mean your testimonial is more relevant in decisions.

For Round 5, Impact Garden gathered over 100 testimonials for 35+ projects in the round. These testimonials were used by Badgeholders during the review process particularly to determine if projects were in the right sub-category and for additional information.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The audience benefiting the most from the data created by Impact Garden are Badgeholders. 

Through the generation of new data in a standardized format we're bridging the gap and giving numbers, projects and contributions a context about their impact to others within the Collective. This has looked like additional data for Badgeholders in the review process and voting.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
OP Passport supports Optimism Governance by providing users with a verifiable, on-chain identity to track and showcase their governance participation. In decentralized governance, it is often difficult to transparently display contributions, voting history, and achievements. OP Passport addresses this challenge by securely storing governance activities and accomplishments through on-chain attestations within users’ smart wallets.

The tool enables participants to easily demonstrate their active involvement in governance, making it simpler for the community to recognize valuable contributors. Additionally, OP Passport facilitates on-chain endorsements, both public and anonymous, which further enhance transparency and accountability across the governance process.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
OP Passport benefits three key governance participants within the Optimism Collective: delegates, delegators, and badgeholders, all of whom can create their own passports, earn achievements, and give or receive endorsements.

Delegates: OP Passport allows delegates to create an on-chain record of their achievements, showcasing their profile to build trust and increase recognition of their contributions.

Delegators: Delegators can track their delegates' actions and assess how their voting power is used. They can also give and receive endorsements, promoting transparency and accountability.

Badgeholders: Badgeholders can earn achievements and give or receive endorsements, recognizing valuable contributions and fostering transparency in governance.

Through OP Passport, all participants can create passports, earn achievements, and showcase their governance contributions, strengthening transparency and accountability in the Optimism ecosystem.

subcategory: Security audits specifically on the OP Stack or its components.

impactStatement.question: How has your project advanced the development of the OP Stack?
impactStatement.answer:
Cantina/Spearbit has advanced the development of the OP Stack by providing critical security audits and reviews to ensure the robustness and safety of its components. Our team has conducted multiple audits of the OP Stack, including security reviews of Optimism's EAS, which are crucial for cross-chain functionality and gas optimization. Through these audits, we have identified vulnerabilities, suggested optimizations, and collaborated with Optimism team to ensure that the OP Stack is secure and resilient.

Additionally, our continuous monitoring, advisory services, and incident response support help maintain the OP Stack's reliability, safeguarding its smart contracts and infrastructure.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited the most from your work on the OP Stack and how?
impactStatement.answer:
The primary beneficiaries of our work on the OP Stack have been developers and projects building within the Optimism ecosystem, as well as the broader Optimism community. By conducting thorough security audits, we have ensured that developers can deploy secure smart contracts, reducing the risk of exploits and vulnerabilities.

Projects like Omni-x and Decent.xyz, which rely on cross-chain capabilities and transaction efficiency, have directly benefited from our security reviews, enabling them to operate safely and scale their solutions across multiple chains.

Our work has enhanced trust and reliability in the OP Stack, making it safer for both developers and users.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer: While Metagov's general project have not been specifically focused on Optimism's governance, we have had a variety of projects meant to help advance governance in digital communities. From projects like Exit to Community and the Open Source transition calculator (exploring the costs of governance transitions and actualizing progressive decentralization) to projects like KOI Pond (using LLMs to increase sense making), Metagov is exploring research and tools that have a lot of relevant to Optimism and other DAOs/

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: Our work is generally consumed by those who are researching, studying or building systems pertaining to governance. Our community involves those interested in DAOs, coops, commons, and open source projects. The information is open to all and meant to help people enact governance systems that empower individuals and communities.

impactStatement.answer:
We use Soul bound token based on Optimism network, any DAO can use LXDAO's governance mechanism, within LXDAO, every public item needs to go through a proposal to be born, we have designed and implemented a complete set of governance mechanism, so far more than 10 public items have been born in LXDAO!
We adopt Optimism-based point system to determine the contribution, LXPoints is based on Optimism's Soul Bound Token, members earn LXPoints through actual contribution, so far more than 138 members have earned LXPoints through contribution.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Optimism Collective, any member who joins LXDAO will get Optimism based Soul Bound Token by contributing, so far more than 138 members have got LXPonts and 94 members have got LXB (Governance Identity), by using this set of Governance Mechanisms, we also spread the At the same time, Optimismcn.eth incubated by LXDAO is currently ranked 52nd in the Optimism Delegate, and is also deeply involved in Optimism governance.

2. Other DAO organizations, our governance mechanism and Soul Bound Token are completely open source, any DAO organization can adopt this set to start their own DAO governance

3. Web3 newcomers, any newcomer to LXDAO can learn how DAO works, and also learn about on-chain governance, DAO operation mode, etc. Currently, LXDAO has 542 registered members.
https://lxdao.io/buidlers

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
RetroList, a project discovery platform for OP Retro Funding, significantly supports Optimism governance by providing detailed analytics and accessible data across Retro Funding rounds 3 to 6.

RetroList also offers detailed analytics for each round, including:
- Project reward distribution across different reward groups
- Project reward distribution by category
- Public crowdsourcing lists for RetroPGF 3
- Metrics distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Open-source vs. closed-source project distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Project reward breakdown by impact metrics for Retro Funding 4

Additionally, RetroList has provided an API that enables direct data queries by other projects like DeVouch and Impact Garden.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Every stakeholder in the Retro Funding process benefits from RetroList, including:
- Any user can discover Retro Funding projects and get inspiration to build on the Superchain.
- Project owners have a UI to check if their project has gone through correctly.
- Badgeholders, delegates, and the OP Foundation have access to the RetroList analytics, which has an impact on badgeholders' voting decisions and the design of future Retro Funding rounds.
- Ecosystem projects have access to the API for querying project data within a few days after the sign-up period and maintain a stable schema.

The RetroList API has been used internally by the DeVouch and Impact Garden projects.

Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Optimystics Tools has supported Optimism Governance by providing and maintaining essential infrastructure for decentralized decision-making over the past year:

1. Initial Toolset: Our core tools have facilitated weekly Optimism Fractal events, enabling consistent governance experimentation and community building.

2. Respect Infrastructure: We've maintained and upgraded the system for distributing Respect tokens, enabling a decentralized distribution amongst leading builders and governance enthusiasts.

3. Council Support: Our tools have enabled the weekly formation and operation of the Optimism Fractal council, demonstrating scalable governance models and creating a well-organized governance body for the Collective.

This consistent infrastructure has allowed for the release of next-generation tools like ORDAO, Fractalgram, and the Respect Games app. It’s enabled a community-driven effort with multiple development teams contributing to a growing toolkit of fractal governance tooling

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Builders, leaders, delegates, and other key stakeholders in the Collective have used our tools at Optimism Fractal events to earn Respect and contribute to decentralized decision-making experiments.

2. Our open-source infrastructure has served as a foundation for further governance innovations on Optimism, empowering researchers and developers interested in decentralized governance.

3. Our tools have provided models and insights that could enhance various governance processes, including the Token House, Citizens' House, RetroFunding, and the Anti-Capture Commission.

4. Other groups like the ZAO Fractal have adopted processes to engage, govern, and grow their communities on the Superchain. 

Our tools have created a vibrant testbed for governance innovations, benefiting anyone interested in exploring and contributing to decentralized decision-making processes on Optimism, and providing valuable data and experiences that can inform the evolution of the Collective's governance.

subcategory: Security audits specifically on the OP Stack or its components.

impactStatement.question: How has your project advanced the development of the OP Stack?
impactStatement.answer:
Cantina/Spearbit has advanced the development of the OP Stack by providing critical security audits and reviews to ensure the robustness and safety of its components. Our team has conducted multiple audits of the OP Stack, including security reviews of Optimism's EAS, which are crucial for cross-chain functionality and gas optimization. Through these audits, we have identified vulnerabilities, suggested optimizations, and collaborated with Optimism team to ensure that the OP Stack is secure and resilient.

Additionally, our continuous monitoring, advisory services, and incident response support help maintain the OP Stack's reliability, safeguarding its smart contracts and infrastructure.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited the most from your work on the OP Stack and how?
impactStatement.answer:
The primary beneficiaries of our work on the OP Stack have been developers and projects building within the Optimism ecosystem, as well as the broader Optimism community. By conducting thorough security audits, we have ensured that developers can deploy secure smart contracts, reducing the risk of exploits and vulnerabilities.

Projects like Omni-x and Decent.xyz, which rely on cross-chain capabilities and transaction efficiency, have directly benefited from our security reviews, enabling them to operate safely and scale their solutions across multiple chains.

Our work has enhanced trust and reliability in the OP Stack, making it safer for both developers and users.

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Token House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering high-context feedback from engaged community members during the design phase, rather than after designs are finalized. By consulting the Foundation on early-stage drafts, we ensure that input from top delegates and governance leads directly shapes decisions as they are being developed. CFC members provided feedback on any drafts shared by the Optimism Foundation. This approach marks a significant first step toward deeper community involvement in the governance design process, aligning with the long-term goal of increased community ownership. 

More details can be found here:
- Introducing the Collective Feedback Commission
https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863
- The Path to Open Metagovernance
https://gov.optimism.io/t/the-path-to-open-metagovernance/7728

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The CFC Token House achieved its mandate by providing high-context feedback on 15 documents during Season 6, aligning with the Optimism Foundation's goal of reducing dependency on the Foundation in governance design. 

Key impacts include:
- Eliminated Trust Tiers from Season 6 grant applications.
- Implemented a 72-hour response SLA for the Developer Advisory Board (DAB).
- Clarified retro reward eligibility and expanded “stakeholders” scope.
- Strengthened Chain Delegation Program with clearer criteria.
- Refined the Superchain strategy, leading to the Vision AMA.

Based on this success, the Commission will continue into its next iteration. More details here:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/collective-feedback-commission-pilot-retrospective/8970

Reward split:
The rewards split for CFC members was based on the number of reviews each completed.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Ptp8e3G5IfJi62aStBjOvNoJnH69glley_qWa3L6j-0/edit?usp=sharing

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Each Badgeholder session has had a different focus given that the needs are matched according to the stage of RetroRounds and the current experiments being carried out:

1. Workshops on the creation of lists for 3 different categories prior to RetroRound3. I designed and ran the workshops in a couple of them with the support of 2 other Badgeholders.
2. Istanbul Meetup @ Onchain Summit where we gathered to 1) connect, 2) explore thoughts on lists and voting, 3) learn about projects such as Pairwise. Secured a place with the OP team, created merch, and coordinated with Badgeholders attending DevConnect. 
3. Badgies Workshopping @ Eth Denver: Coordinated the event, contacted the presenting teams, and led the session.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Each session has led to different improvements in the process and experiments of RetroRounds. 
For the first two, the outcomes are described above. 

For the 3 Session, here is some additional information:

In this session the following teams presented and received feedback from Badgeholders and the Foundation:
1. EZKL - https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz/
2. Buidl Guild - Metrics Based Voting
3. Agora 
4. Pairwise
5. EasyRPGF

 This session particularly informed changes in the design of voting for Round 4, the release of EZKL's proving system for Retro3 results, among other things.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
FairSharing is a collaboration tool based on the Optimism network, where anyone and any organization can use FairSharing to achieve collaboration and distribution. FairSharing can publicly and transparently record everyone's contributions, and nearly 50 organizations and projects are currently using FairSharing to record contributions.

The underlying layer of FairSharing uses EAS as a record of contributions. When users confirm their contributions, they need to submit their Claim requests on the Optimism network to receive their incentive shares.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Optimism Collective: Anyone on Optimism can register and allocate based on FairSharing, and it provides fundamental governance tools.

2. DAOs: Collaboration within DAOs requires transparency and traceability. FairSharing can meet this need, and ultimately all records will be chain-stored, fulfilling the requirement for transparency.

3. Public Goods Projects: It can assist public goods in better tracking contributions, recording contributors to public goods, and facilitating the subsequent tracing of impact and incentives.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history
Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
A Vault is a secure smart contract that functions as a simple, safe savings account for your hot wallet. It allows you to deposit tokens and NFTs, set withdrawal limits, whitelist addresses, and require multiple signers for transactions. Vaults help keep your assets safe from drainers, hacks, open approvals, and lost or leaked private keys, making it an effective way to enhance the security and management of your digital assets.

We built in the abilty to allow delegates to easily delegate their tokens securely from their vault. This supports governance processes while maintaining asset safety for users.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Delegators
Delegators have greatly benefited from the Vault's security features. By using the Vault to delegate tokens securely, delegators can confidently participate in governance processes without risking the transfer of tokens to third parties or insecure platforms byusing hot wallets. This ensures that their delegated assets remain protected from hacks, drainers, and other malicious activities and gives them a simple way to delegate vs exchanges which cant.

This enhances the overall participation in Optimism’s decentralized governance by lowering barriers to involvement while maintaining security.

Delegates
Delegates, who are entrusted with the critical role of voting on behalf of token holders, have been one of the key beneficiaries of the Vault's infrastructure. Through the Vault, delegates can receive more votes securely, enabling them to effectively get larger delegations.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
GovXS analyzed the voting designs used in Optimism Retro Funding across Rounds 1–4, focusing on whether voters were incentivized to truthfully report their preferences. Our analysis uncovered a critical flaw: none of the voting rules applied so far are strategyproof! 
In other words, voters can gain an advantage by not voting according to their true preferences. To fix this, we proposed two alternative voting solutions, along with clear, actionable recommendations for their implementation.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
a) **Optimism Retro Funding Program:** GovXS’s advanced analytics have empowered the OP Retro Funding Program to identify and solve critical flaws and enable a strategyproof voting that upholds the integrity of retro funding.
b) **Optimism Retro Funding badgeholders, experts, and guest voters:** Badgeholders, experts and guest voters gain trust that voting outcomes reflect the true preferences of all participants.
c) **Optimism Retro Funding projects:** With GovXS’s analytics-driven recommendations, Optimism Retro Funding projects have confidence in a voting process that guarantees fair compensation through transparent, objective assessments.
d) **Superchain Ecosystem:** Optimism’s Retro Funding strives to achieve a true, fair allocation of rewards. Flawed voting rules distort outcomes, preventing Optimism Retro Funding from realizing its goal of aligning 'Impact = Profit.' GovXs’s analysis provided actionable solutions to safeguard this vision for the long term.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Impact Calculator played a pivotal role in shaping the design and accelerating the development of Retro Funding 4, which focused primarily on measuring the tangible impact of each project rather than their popularity. 

Our research focused on converting raw data into a quantifiable metric, providing a clearer, more objective way to estimate the real-world contributions of each project. This innovation streamlined the evaluation process for badgeholders, enabling them to spend less time on assessments while ensuring that projects with the highest impact received the recognition and support they deserved.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Small builders especially benefit from our findings, as they no longer need to focus on large, well-known projects to gain the funding they deserve. By creating impactful projects, even on a smaller scale, they can access Retro Funding, which rewards contributions based on impact rather than recognition.

Badgeholders also benefit from this approach, as we’ve automated much of the data they previously needed to review manually. This simplification makes the voting process more efficient, allowing them to focus on evaluating projects quickly and accurately, while maintaining a fair and transparent funding process.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We built this site in response to forum feedback, where many community members shared feeling overwhelmed by the constantly evolving nature of Optimism governance, in particular the many novel experiments around grant programs.

While rapid iteration is good for innovation (yay!), it also made it more challenging to stay up-to-date without first having to "navigate a maze of forum posts". We made it easy to access all deadlines and changes to programs in one place.

This has been well received: In the period between Oct 2023 and Sept 2024, there have been 2.9K outbound link clicks from our site to the Charmverse Grants Council page, 1.1K clicks to the Foundation Mission Requests pages on GitHub, and 605 clicks to forum posts on Retro Funding Rounds.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Our site has primarily been useful as tool for supporting those involved in grants processes, including the Grants Council, Retro Funding Rounds and (Foundation) Mission Requests.

The subscribers of our newsletter though which we used to share weekly updates, before then focusing primarily on the website, included employees from OP Labs, OpenZeppelin and Wakeup Labs. 

Grant applicants from projects such as OpenZeppelin are also those who benefited most from our overview of the current status of grant programs, upcoming deadlines, and the changelog. They otherwise would have had a much higher workload by having to keep track of this information across a number of different channels (GitHub, Grants Council Charmverse page, Forum, ...)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Citizens House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering hight-context feedback from highly engaged Citizens during the design phase of RetroRounds in multiple levels and stages of the process. In the initial scope, members were expected to spend an average of 5 hours per Round/Season providing feedback, with work starting on April 1st for 6 months where feedback would be provided for Rounds 4 and 5 only.  

The work developed by the Citizens House Feedback Commission marks a significant step towards setting the foundations for the decentralization of the metagovernance design process.

More information on the initial scope of work for the Commission can be found here: 
- Introducing the Collective Feedback Commission
https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863

https://gov.optimism.io/t/the-path-to-open-metagovernance/7728

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Citizen’s FC achieved it's mandate and initial scope of work by providing feedback to 8 documents for Rounds 4 and 5. 
Impact as stated by the Foundation can be found here:https://bit.ly/4f2s3bW

Additionally, we exceeded our mandate by crafting the proposal of a Mission Request, providing feedback for Optimism’s Decentralization Milestones, Optimism’s Product Vision, Backstopped Grants and Round 6; extending our work into early October.
Feedback led to:
1. Changes in the scope of Round 6 and it’s sub-categories
2. Increase in the resources provided by the Foundation for context setting for the Decentralization Milestones such as: explainer post, loom video, additional frameworks.
3. Feedback on the Product Vision led to “moderate edits” and was “very useful” to demonstrate opportunity areas in the communications from the Foundation.

Based on the impact generated, the Commission will become a permanent structure:
https://bit.ly/4h6CJs7

Reward split:
https://bit.ly/4h6CugH

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Grants Council is to oversee the evaluation and approval of projects for Governance Fund grants, ensuring they align with the season's intent andthe mission requests.  

Key responsibilities include:

1. Grant Evaluation: Reviewing and approving grant applications that further the goals of The Collective.
2. Ensuring transparency by publishing reports, tracking milestone progress, and maintaining open communication with the community.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Grants Council keeps an updated communication thread here: 
https://gov.optimism.io/t/s5-grants-council-communication-thread/8034

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The WalletConnect Network is used to allow the user of any wallet that is on the network to participate in governance. https://explorer.walletconnect.com/.
In September 2024, users from over 25 different wallets have used this tooling to participate in the Optimism voting for Season 5 including Metamask mobile, Rainbow, Candide, Trust Wallet, Ledger Live, BitGet, Binance Web3Wallet and OKX wallet - which ensures users can retain choice over where they keep their assets and how they participate in voting. 
Because WalletConnect is built for both desktop and mobile, users can vote from their mobile devices - over 25% of the connections provided by the network in the last 30 days have come from mobile voters.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main beneficiaries of the WalletConnect Network, with respect to voting, are the voters and the Optimism Development team. The voter is able to choose the wallet that they want to use when participating in governance. This ensures that users are not constrained to a small number of wallets.
The simplified integration process, tried and tested by over 6000 different applications also means the Optimism development team can easily offer this connectivity to their voters with minimal technical work ensuring compatibility with the widest range of wallets.

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history
Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Optimystics Tools has supported Optimism Governance by providing and maintaining essential infrastructure for decentralized decision-making over the past year:

1. Initial Toolset: Our core tools have facilitated weekly Optimism Fractal events, enabling consistent governance experimentation and community building.

2. Respect Infrastructure: We've maintained and upgraded the system for distributing Respect tokens, enabling a decentralized distribution amongst leading builders and governance enthusiasts.

3. Council Support: Our tools have enabled the weekly formation and operation of the Optimism Fractal council, demonstrating scalable governance models and creating a well-organized governance body for the Collective.

This consistent infrastructure has allowed for the release of next-generation tools like ORDAO, Fractalgram, and the Respect Games app. It’s enabled a community-driven effort with multiple development teams contributing to a growing toolkit of fractal governance tooling

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Builders, leaders, delegates, and other key stakeholders in the Collective have used our tools at Optimism Fractal events to earn Respect and contribute to decentralized decision-making experiments.

2. Our open-source infrastructure has served as a foundation for further governance innovations on Optimism, empowering researchers and developers interested in decentralized governance.

3. Our tools have provided models and insights that could enhance various governance processes, including the Token House, Citizens' House, RetroFunding, and the Anti-Capture Commission.

4. Other groups like the ZAO Fractal have adopted processes to engage, govern, and grow their communities on the Superchain. 

Our tools have created a vibrant testbed for governance innovations, benefiting anyone interested in exploring and contributing to decentralized decision-making processes on Optimism, and providing valuable data and experiences that can inform the evolution of the Collective's governance.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history
Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Since Giveth’s launch of DeVouch in June until Sep 18th, there were over 700 attestations made, with over 150 being for projects in Retro Funding 4 & 5. Our modular tool allows anyone to lend their credibility to projects that are applying for RetroFunding rounds, as well as fundraising on Gitcoin & Giveth. 

DeVouch is built in a modular way that allows any grant program to add their projects & any attestor groups to add their reputation. Our default UI allows badgeholders to see in a glance how many people of relevant reputation vouch for the project; e.g. you can quickly see that 2 RF4 Badgeholders, 3 OP Delegates, 11 Gitcoin Passport Holders, 1 RF5 Voter, & 1 Giveth Verifier all [vouched for EAS](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf5).

Every project that applied to RF4 & RF5, even those that were rejected, were able to be vouched for, or flagged during the review period. Many of the rejected projects were accurately flagged by the community on DeVouch.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The OP community (esp. delegates) can support projects that are adding value to the Superchain Community. While unable to participate in Retro Funding directly, through DeVouch, they can lend their credibility to them, and leave a comment about the project using our extremely easy to use UX. [Try it out!](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf6)

Voters & reviewers in Retro Funding programs are able to incorporate the wisdom of the crowds. 

We helped the Foundation prevent imposters. DeVouch made tweets tagging every project that applied in RF5. If impersonation occurred, the project would have seen the tweet, flagged it on DeVouch and reported it.

Projects have a simple way to prove their legitimacy in an industry ripe with scams. Giveth also ran 9 QF rounds (7 hosted on Superchain networks), raising over [$865k for projects](https://giveth.io/qf-archive) like EAS, Pairwise & growthepie alongside projects that are making irl impact like Palestine Children's Relief Fund or the EFF.

Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: The Ethereans Protocol allows a more decentralized and transparent framework for governance. Our Organizations product enables anyone to create fully decentralized DAOs on Optimism, reducing dependence on centralized entities like the Foundation to set funding parameters. These DAOs can manage treasuries, vote on proposals, and automate token actions through on-chain factory contracts, allowing governance to be handled directly by the community. With our modular tooling, communities can actively participate in shaping funding rounds through decentralized voting mechanisms, ensuring that decision-making is fair, transparent, and inclusive. By utilizing Ethereans' Organizations, Optimism’s RPGF process can evolve to reflect its ethos of decentralization, granting more influence and ownership to participants. This will not only improve the fairness of funding decisions but also foster innovation in governance models, positioning Optimism as a leader in decentralized governance

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The primary beneficiaries of Ethereans Protocol’s infrastructure and tooling are governance participants within the Optimism ecosystem who seek a decentralized and transparent governance process:

DAO Founders & Builders – Our Organizations product enables them to create and manage decentralized governance structures without technical expertise, eliminating the need for central control.

Token Holders & Voters – Token holders can participate in decision-making through on-chain voting, ensuring their voices are heard and proposals are recorded immutably.

RPGF Participants – Contributors and grantees benefit from a fair funding process governed by decentralized DAOs, prioritizing community input and engagement.

Optimism Delegates – Delegates can leverage our tooling to automate and streamline governance processes

With this infrastructure, Ethereans Protocol promotes decentralized decision-making, accountability, and community participation across all layers of governance in Optimism.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer: Successfully completed a token house governance growth mission titled [Integrate Optimism Governance into University Module], and hosted governance workshops, community calls, and events throughout the year for Seasons 5 (S5) and 6 (S6).

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
We successfully completed a significant governance mission, positioning Optimism as the first university-level blockchain course in Costa Rica.

Our efforts have enhanced the governance process by fostering community engagement and education within the Optimism ecosystem in the country, through the "Integrate Optimism Governance into University Module" mission. Not to mention that this module can now be replicated anywhere anytime. Our work has positioned Optimism and is attracting attention from other universities and organizations

We organized gov workshops, community calls, and events throughout the year [OP Days] This initiative has increased participation in governance, missions, and the forum.

By facilitating hands-on experiences, we empowered students to collaborate on innovative solutions, enriching the governance framework with diverse perspectives.

Creating the next generation of Optimism leaders, ensuring a robust future for the ecosystem!

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer: The Security Council carried out its role of signing protocol upgrades approved by the Token House in accordance with the Internal Operating Procedures set out by the council. In Season 6 the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1, where the Foundation multisig was removed from the Upgrade multisig, and the Security Council became the sole signer.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
In Season 6, the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1. A requirement for Phase 1 is that a 75% signing threshold is met for all upgrades. This requires 10 out of 13 signatures. Security Council members continued to engage swiftly when action was required. The following upgrades were signed during Season 6:

### Protocol Upgrade 10 — Granite Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: September 6 - September 10
🥳 Status: Executed September 11 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 9 — Fjord Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: June 26 - July 2
🥳 Status: Executed July 10 with 12/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 8 — Changes for Stage 1 Decentralization
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 7 — Fault Proofs
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Since Giveth’s launch of DeVouch in June until September 18th, there were about 700 attestations made, with over 150 being for projects in Retro Funding 4 & 5. Our tool, similar to Metrics Garden, allows anyone to lend their credibility to projects that are applying for RetroFunding rounds, as well as fundraising on Gitcoin & Giveth. 

Every project that applied to RF4 & RF5, even those that were rejected, were able to be vouched for, or flagged. Many of the rejected projects were accurately flagged by the community on DeVouch. 

Also, Giveth ran 9 QF rounds (7 hosted on Superchain networks), raising over [$865k for projects](https://giveth.io/qf-archive) like EAS, Pairwise, DAOstar, Praise & growthepie (supporting OP Governance) alongside projects that are making real world impact like Palestine Children's Relief Fund or the EFF. Projects’ order of appearance in the rounds could be changed by using our GIVpower governance system on OP mainnet.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
DeVouch is built in a modular way that allows any grant program to add their projects and any attestor groups to add their reputation. Our default UI allows badgeholders to see in a glance how many people of relevant reputation vouch for the project. For example, you can quickly see that 2 RF 4 Badgeholder, 3 OP Delegates, 11 Gitcoin Passports, 1 RF 5 Voter, & 1 Giveth Verifier all [vouched for EAS](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf5).

Flagging projects is especially helpful. DeVouch made tweets tagging every project that applied in RF5 to ensure there were no imposters posing to be them in the round. If there would have been an imposter, the project would have seen the tweet, been able to flag it on DeVouch and report it to the Foundation.

On the fundraising side, Giveth enabled EAS, Pairwise, DAOstar, Praise, growthepie, and several other OP Governance-related projects to collect much needed funds to continue their work in the Collective.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The **Delegate Match Farcaster Frame** is designed to improve accessibility in Optimism governance by helping OP token holders find active delegates who align with their values and vision. The tool streamlines the process, allowing users to take an 11-question survey and match with active, values-aligned delegates, increasing the overall votable OP supply. [Landing page](https://delegatematch.xyz/)

Leveraging Farcaster’s 650K registered users and 60-100K daily active users, Delegate Match boosts exposure to the OP delegation process. Our Farcaster Frame provides a seamless experience, enabling users to make an informed decision and delegate their tokens in just five minutes. By integrating the Ethereum Attestation Service, Delegate Match supports delegate reputation-building. It provides OP holders and delegates a low-cost, high-impact, innovative delegation tool. [Onchain Metrics](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/rJaRn0UJJe)

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main beneficiaries of **Delegate Match** are OP token holders who aren’t too engaged in governance and OP delegates with active delegations. Holders can easily find and delegate or redelegate to active delegates who align with their values. OP delegates, particularly underrepresented ones, benefit from increased visibility to grow their delegations based on values alignment rather than popularity. By encouraging broader participation, Delegate Match helps decentralize governance and promotes greater equity among delegates, enabling them to play a more meaningful role in Optimism's decision-making.


This product, built for Optimism governance, is currently in its **MVP** stage. Our next steps include improving the user experience, enhancing impact tracking, and launching a marketing campaign to increase the overall votable OP supply. Funding will ensure we gain traction and continue the development [Vision and Features Roadmap](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/HJaVrJw1ye)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Security Council carried out its role of signing protocol upgrades approved by the Token House in accordance with the Internal Operating Procedures set out by the Security Council. 

In Season 6 the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1, as part of this upgrade the owner of the L2ProxyAdmin contract was reassigned from the Foundation to the Security Council.

As part of Phase 1, the signing threshold for the Security Council was increased from 4 to 10. Throughout Season 6, the Security Council continued it's streak of meeting quorum on all signing ceremonies. 

As part of Phase 1, the role of Guardian was reassigned from the Foundation to a new Guardian Safe with the Security Council Safe as its sole owner, moving Optimism closer to satisfying the 1 week exit window required for Stage 1.
