subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was created to prevent capture of the Token House by any single tokenholder or group, including protocols and OP Chains. It represents high-impact individual delegates and acts as a communication bridge between the Token House and Citizens' House, addressing imbalances in power and maintaining governance integrity.
 
Relevant Documentation:
Anticapture Commission Mandate: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission/6889

Anticapture Commission Communication Thread:  https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/9


Season 6 Internal Operating Procedures: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-s6-internal-operating-procedures-iop/8637

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During S6 Governance (VC #25 to #28), ACC voted on the Dolomite Network upgrade proposal. ACC held discussions and shared feedback to the Foundation on the Dolomite Upgrade Proposal on certain technical aspects of the upgrade that the ACC members felt could have been better implemented. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/20 ) 

During S6 voting cycles, few Delegates encountered voting issues on the Agora UI, resulting in wrongly cast votes during a mission request vote. The ACC held internal discussions on the issue and took it up with the Agora team and worked towards resolving the issue. 


The ACC also held a call to discuss the Accelerated Decentralization Proposal for Optimism with GFX Labs and the Foundation. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/accelerated-decentralization-proposal-for-optimism/8875/32 ) 
 
Since the Start of Season 6 of Governance, votable supply has increased by 7.31%, from 89.4m OP to 96m OP.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Gitcoin developed the voting interfaces for Retrofunding 4 & Retrofunding 5, which were used by badgeholders to allocate funds during those rounds.

For RF4, we worked closely with Open Source Observer and Optimism to implement new metrics-based discovery, selection, and weighting. Our solution allowed users to filter and evaluate projects based on various impact metrics. 

For both RF 4 & RF5, we created a user-friendly interface for governance participants to allocate their votes. 

These tools are primarily used within Optimism Governance to support the Retroactive Public Goods Funding process, which is a crucial part of Optimism's governance model. They aim to make the process of discovering, evaluating, and voting for projects more efficient, transparent, and user-friendly for governance participants.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The direct benefits are the Optimism badgeholders and recipients of Retrofunding. During RF4, 108 out of 133 badgeholders participated. $10M OP tokens were allocated to 207 projects. 

Though RF5 is still ongoing at the time of this application, participation is high. Badgeholders are expected to allocate between 2-8m OP tokens to up to 89 projects.

The team has also integrated these features into EasyRetroPGF.xyz, which makes them available to a wider range of users involved in Optimism's governance processes. The SUNNYS Awards have also been built on this same technology!

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
DeepDAO provides the most comprehensive analysis of different components of Optimism governance:

- Treasury, including trends over time, tokens, assets and composition (OP vs stables, majors, and others).

-  Token, including governance performance influence on the OP token price.

- Voter Trends: multiple metrics of quality and intensity of governance participation in the Collective. Successful proposals, avg. votes per proposal, and others, in multiple timeframes. We also categorize voters based on their governance score to understand participant quality.

- Delegation, including intensity, and quantity of involvement across voting power, delegators, total votes, and voting periods.

- Delegate Coalitions, tracking governance activity of power groups of up to 6 addresses. Together with Delegation, this provides deep analysis of decentralization within Optimism governance.

- Voters Ecosystem, measuring the Collective voters involvement in other DAOs, including competing DAOs.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
New Participants: DeepDAO helps new entrants to the DAO ecosystem discover the OP Collective, ensuring they do not face information asymmetry compared to experienced participants.

Delegates use DeepDAO to stay updated on OP Collective activities. Our analytics dashboard offers extensive information on the DAO's well-being.

Builders: DeepDAO makes it easy for builders to identify and approach the right delegates for feedback. (using the Delegation, and Coalitions dashboards).

Tooling Providers: DeepDAO aggregates information across various tooling providers and includes a tools page listing all DAO tools available to the Optimism Collective.

OP Collective: Our data on coalitions, governance segmentation and voter trends provides multiple indicators of the DAO’s decentralization, governance resilience and security. The Collective benefits immensely from a free resource like DeepDAO.

Investors, journalists, researchers: 1000s of media articles and academic papers quote DeepDAO data.

- **Provided Value for Governance Delegates & Badgeholders**: Presented clear, impactful applications for more informed decisions supporting long-term goals.
- **Spread Governance Participation to the Broader Optimism Ecosystem**: Benefited from efficient capital allocation, supporting

Holders can easily find and delegate or redelegate to active delegates who align with their values. OP delegates, particularly underrepresented ones, benefit from increased visibility to grow their delegations based on values alignment rather than popularity. By encouraging broader participation, Delegate Match helps decentralize governance and promotes greater equity among delegates, enabling them to play a more meaningful role in Optimism's decision-making.

We have a solid foundation and are passionately engaged in exploring innovative solutions in this uncharted territory. Our focus includes critical inquiries into user experience, impact tracking, and outreach strategies so that delegation is informed, accessible, accountable, and efficient for all stakeholders. Delve into our [Vision and Insights](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/HJaVrJw1ye)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Citizens House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering hight-context feedback from highly engaged Citizens during the design phase of RetroRounds in multiple levels and stages of the process. impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Impact Garden is used to gather standardized information on a project's impact to the Optimism Collective beyond that being self reported by applicants. The information collected is linked to the reputation of the person providing the testimonial enabling advanced weighting by the consumer of the data. Higher reputation in the Collective, can mean your testimonial is more relevant in decisions.

For Round 5, Impact Garden gathered over 100 testimonials for 35+ projects in the round. These testimonials were used by Badgeholders during the review process particularly to determine if projects were in the right sub-category and for additional information.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The audience benefiting the most from the data created by Impact Garden are Badgeholders. 

Through the generation of new data in a standardized format we're bridging the gap and giving numbers, projects and contributions a context about their impact to others within the Collective. This has looked like additional data for Badgeholders in the review process and voting.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?

Better vibes

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was created to prevent capture of the Token House by any single tokenholder or group, including protocols and OP Chains. It represents high-impact individual delegates and acts as a communication bridge between the Token House and Citizens' House, addressing imbalances in power and maintaining governance integrity.

Anticapture Commission Mandate: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission/6889

Anticapture Commission Communication Thread:  https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/9

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During S6 Governance (VC #25 to #28), ACC voted on the Dolomite Network upgrade proposal. ACC held discussions and shared feedback to the Foundation on the Dolomite Upgrade Proposal on certain technical aspects of the upgrade that the ACC members felt could have been better implemented. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/20 ) 

During S6 voting cycles, few Delegates encountered voting issues on the Agora UI, resulting in wrongly cast votes during a mission request vote. The ACC held internal discussions on the issue and took it up with the Agora team and worked towards resolving the issue. 


The ACC also held a call to discuss the Accelerated Decentralization Proposal for Optimism with GFX Labs and the Foundation. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/accelerated-decentralization-proposal-for-optimism/8875/32 ) 
 
Since the Start of Season 6 of Governance, votable supply has increased by 7.31%, from 89.4m OP to 96m OP.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Since Giveth’s launch of DeVouch in June until September 18th, there were about 700 attestations made, with over 150 being for projects in Retro Funding 4 & 5. Our tool, similar to Metrics Garden, allows anyone to lend their credibility to projects that are applying for RetroFunding rounds, as well as fundraising on Gitcoin & Giveth. 

Every project that applied to RF4 & RF5, even those that were rejected, were able to be vouched for, or flagged. Many of the rejected projects were accurately flagged by the community on DeVouch. 

Also, Giveth ran 9 QF rounds (7 hosted on Superchain networks), raising over [$865k for projects](https://giveth.io/qf-archive) like EAS, Pairwise, DAOstar, Praise & growthepie (supporting OP Governance) alongside projects that are making real world impact like Palestine Children's Relief Fund or the EFF. Projects’ order of appearance in the rounds could be changed by using our GIVpower governance system on OP mainnet.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
DeVouch is built in a modular way that allows any grant program to add their projects and any attestor groups to add their reputation. Our default UI allows badgeholders to see in a glance how many people of relevant reputation vouch for the project. For example, you can quickly see that 2 RF 4 Badgeholder, 3 OP Delegates, 11 Gitcoin Passports, 1 RF 5 Voter, & 1 Giveth Verifier all [vouched for EAS](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf5).

Flagging projects is especially helpful. DeVouch made tweets tagging every project that applied in RF5 to ensure there were no imposters posing to be them in the round. If there would have been an imposter, the project would have seen the tweet, been able to flag it on DeVouch and report it to the Foundation.

On the fundraising side, Giveth enabled EAS, Pairwise, DAOstar, Praise, growthepie, and several other OP Governance-related projects to collect much needed funds to continue their work in the Collective.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Our analysis measures the participation and behavior of Badgeholders in the Superchain ecosystem, specifically focusing on their transaction activities across networks like OP Mainnet, Base, Zora, and Mode. It also examines their engagement in decentralized applications (DEXs), token transfers, and social platforms like Farcaster. 

A key insight is the relatively low activity level of Badgeholders compared to Non-Badgeholders, particularly in areas like DEX trading and smart contract deployment. Additionally, the analysis tracks how Badgeholders' preferences for Ethereum transactions and limited cross-chain activity impact their overall engagement with Optimism's governance processes. 

This helps identify where governance structures may need to be adjusted to include better and activate Badgeholders, ensuring their participation grows alongside the broader ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Collective has benefitted most from this analysis, gaining valuable insights into Badgeholder behavior that inform strategies to increase engagement. For example, understanding that Badgeholders are more active on Ethereum but less engaged with smart contract deployment helps the Collective target these users with specific governance initiatives. 

Furthermore, the findings around Farcaster connections show the importance of social engagement within this group, which can shape future governance outreach and participation efforts. The insights have also helped governance teams refine their strategies for promoting cross-chain activity and diversifying user engagement. This research will also guide the future selection of new Badgeholders for the Citizen House by identifying gaps and ensuring the House becomes more inclusive and representative of the entire user profile within the Collective, promoting a well-rounded governance structure.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer: The mandate of govNERDs was to enhance governance accessibility by taking on key responsibilities that streamline the proposal process, such as guiding proposals through feedback, approval, and voting stages. We facilitated collaboration among proposers, ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods, and maintained onboarding hubs for both Token House and Citizens' House. Our work aimed to ensure high-quality engagement in the governance forum while reducing the administrative burden on the Optimism Foundation, thus enabling a smoother and more inclusive governance process.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During Season 5, govNERDs successfully reduced the Foundation’s workload by taking over key governance responsibilities. We managed Voting Cycle Roundups, drafted vote copy, and handled announcements for voting and veto cycles, making the governance process more efficient. govNERDs also ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods during the first season of Citizen’s House governance and maintained the Token House and Citizens’ House Onboarding Hubs. Additionally, our efforts in monitoring the forum, answering community questions, and providing feedback in retrospectives significantly enhanced delegate and Citizen experiences. This performance exceeded our mandate by streamlining operations and setting the stage for an open contribution path in Season 6.

[Reflection on the contributions of govNERDs in Season 5 made by the Foundation](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem-contributions/issues/114#issuecomment-2091050734)

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Governance Vulnerability Discovery (Jan, 2024 - Oct 18, 2024)
During the specified time period, we uncovered and reported a significant governance vulnerability related to voting power discrepancies within the Optimism governance framework. 

Vulnerability Identification
In August 2024, we discovered a critical issue where certain addresses had disproportionately high voting power, exceeding their actual token holdings. This created the risk of skewing governance decisions and breaking the "one token, one vote" principle, which is foundational to decentralized governance. There was >200,000 OP which were double voted.
The vulnerability allows certain addresses to retain voting power for >200,000 OP even after selling the tokens, effectively doubling their influence. They could split their holdings to create multiple top 100 delegate spots for 0 token cost, further increasing their power, posing a zero-cost attack risk.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
The vulnerability was reported promptly to the Optimism governance team, ensuring that the issue was addressed before it could materially impact governance outcomes in future voting cycles.

Collaborative Resolution
After reporting the issue, we worked with the Optimism team to clarify the problem and assist in formulating a fix. 
The governance team implemented a fix that removed the inflated delegations and prevented such issues from happening in future voting cycles.
The prompt resolution and transparency around the issue maintained the integrity of the OP governance system
Token House and RetroPGF Consideration
This discovery did not fall under a formal bounty program or RetroPGF framework, the Optimism governance team acknowledged the importance of the contribution and allowed for RPGF. This recognition emphasized the value of community-driven governance security efforts, even in the absence of formalized bounty structures.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We have helped Optimism governance participants by aggregating and condensing the forum activity (and the limited snapshot data) so they can easily stay on top of what is occurring in the DAO. Users quickly get a newsfeed in both chronological and 'trending' orders, with each topic condensed in a structured format for easy readability.
We have also had our telegram governance assistant bot available during this time, helping get direct answers for governance participants quickly.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Governance participants who are new to Optimism and/or participating in multiple DAOs have benefited most from our tooling. This is because they do not have the historic context or understanding as someone who is deep in Optimism governance, so they use our tool to get a better understanding and to dive deeper into certain areas. E.g. we surface related content for each topic, so users can explore the history or related topics for a certain subject matter. Our governance assistant bot also quickly surfaces relevant information based on what users ask, e.g. 'what is rgpf and when is the next round?'.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We built this site in response to forum feedback, where many community members shared feeling overwhelmed by the constantly evolving nature of Optimism governance, in particular the many novel experiments around grant programs.

While rapid iteration is good for innovation (yay!), it also made it more challenging to stay up-to-date without first having to "navigate a maze of forum posts". We made it easy to access all deadlines and changes to programs in one place.

This has been well received: In the period between Oct 2023 and Sept 2024, there have been 2.9K outbound link clicks from our site to the Charmverse Grants Council page, 1.1K clicks to the Foundation Mission Requests pages on GitHub, and 605 clicks to forum posts on Retro Funding Rounds.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Our site has primarily been useful as tool for supporting those involved in grants processes, including the Grants Council, Retro Funding Rounds and (Foundation) Mission Requests.

The subscribers of our newsletter where we used to share weekly updates, before then focusing primarily on the website, include employees from OP Labs, OpenZeppelin and Wakeup Labs. 

The teams behind grantee projects such as OpenZeppelin are those who likely benefited most from our overview of the current status of grant programs, upcoming deadlines, our grants calendar, and the changelog. They otherwise would have had a much higher workload by having to keep track of this information across a number of different channels (GitHub, Grants Council Charmverse page, Forum, ...)

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer: The mandate of govNERDs was to enhance governance accessibility by taking on key responsibilities that streamline the proposal process, such as guiding proposals through feedback, approval, and voting stages. We facilitated collaboration among proposers, ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods, and maintained onboarding hubs for both Token House and Citizens' House. Our work aimed to ensure high-quality engagement in the governance forum while reducing the administrative burden on the Optimism Foundation, thus enabling a smoother and more inclusive governance process.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During Season 5, govNERDs successfully reduced the Foundation’s workload by taking over key governance responsibilities. We managed Voting Cycle Roundups, drafted vote copy, and handled announcements for voting and veto cycles, making the governance process more efficient. govNERDs also ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods during the first season of Citizen’s House governance and maintained the Token House and Citizens’ House Onboarding Hubs. Additionally, our efforts in monitoring the forum, answering community questions, and providing feedback in retrospectives significantly enhanced delegate and Citizen experiences. This performance exceeded our mandate by streamlining operations and setting the stage for an open contribution path in Season 6.

[Reflection on the contributions of govNERDs in Season 5 made by the Foundation](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem-contributions/issues/114#issuecomment-2091050734)

Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Impact Calculator significantly enhanced the decision-making process for Retro Funding 4 by measuring the tangible real-world impact of each project, rather than relying on popularity metrics. This approach aligned with Optimism’s mission to reward high-impact contributions to the ecosystem.

By converting raw data into quantifiable metrics, the tool enabled badgeholders to evaluate projects more objectively and efficiently, reducing assessment time while ensuring impactful projects receive recognition and funding.

Our infrastructure and tooling support Optimism Governance by providing a transparent, data-driven evaluation framework, automating impact assessments, and ensuring fair resource allocation without subjective criteria—advancing the governance goal of fostering sustainable growth.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Small builders have benefited the most from our infrastructure and tooling. They no longer need to compete with large, well-known projects for visibility. By creating impactful contributions, even on a smaller scale, they can access Retro Funding, which rewards based on real-world impact rather than recognition. This levels the playing field for those with fewer resources, enabling them to receive the funding they deserve.

Badgeholders also benefit significantly from our tooling. We’ve automated much of the data they previously had to review manually, streamlining their evaluation process. This allows them to assess projects more quickly and accurately, ensuring a fair and transparent voting process while maintaining the integrity of Optimism Governance.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
**Discord Praise Bot:**

Allows users to praise one another within their community for contributions, which are then stored and minted as on-chain attestations on Optimism Network.

Facilitates community recognition and builds trust through transparent records of contributions.
Since Oct 1st, 2023 to Sep 18th, 2024, We had a total of 642 Praises. Each one a statement of gratitude, as well as reputational data. 

200+ Active users 



**Praise on Farcaster:**

Integrates Praise’s attestation capabilities onto Farcaster. Users can tag @givepraise to publicly appreciate other Farcaster accounts.

Farcaster Frame Praise Attestations lowers the barrier to entry for creating user reputation, contributing to proof of uniqueness and reputation scores across the Web3 ecosystem.

236 attestations minted since the launch on Praise Farcaster bot (within 2 weeks)

76 Unique users minted attestations

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
**Active Participants in Optimism Governance:**

Delegates & Badgeholders:

Can easily show gratitude
Can help community members build onchain reputation. 

Engaged Community Members:
Gain visibility and reputation through peer recognition.
Boosts motivation to participate in governance activities.
Better vibes

**Individuals Verifying Reputations and Identities:**

Onchain Attestations:
Provide a transparent and verifiable record of contributions.
Aid in assessing community members' reputations.

Trust Building:
Help users make informed decisions within governance.
Lower the barrier to entry for new contributors seeking to build trust.

Overall Impact:
Simplified the process of acknowledging contributions and verifying reputations.
Strengthened engagement and collaboration within the Optimism governance ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
- Data interoperability and transparency within the Collective: The Optimism Collective is one of the largest DAOs, with new artifacts being released continuously. This includes information on committees & councils, list of important initiatives, links to governance, list of voters, etc. Through EIP-4824, we have created an on-chain (and off-chain) source of truth on the Optimism Collective. New artifacts can be continuously added to the Collective's daoURI, making it comprehensive over time. 

- Better visibility for DAO-related EAS schemas on Optimism: Currently, there is no place where DAO-related EAS schemas can be listed and indexed, along with a description and additional context. We built a proof-of-concept DAO Schema Registry.

- Visibility into grants. Working with OSO and Gitcoin, we have developed an initial data lake for grants across Web3, including Optimism's grants, combating grant farming and double dipping across ecosystems.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
- Governance tooling providers: More transparency and interoperability of data direclty benefit Snapshot, Snapshot X, and a variety of other governance tools, who utilize EIP-4824 to publish and handle DAO metadata.

- New participants of the OP Collective: the daoURI is a useful piece of infrastructure for anyone who'd like to find info at a single location.

- Delegates: More data transparency and standardization makes it easier for even high-context individuals to assess changes across the scope of a wide, decentralized organization.

Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
As a social influencer, I have actively contributed to the governance of OP Stack by providing insightful analyses and interpretations of its strategies and governance plans. 

My work includes a series of articles that demystify complex concepts related to OP Stack, highlighting its significance in the Ethereum Layer 2 ecosystem. 

Through thorough research and clear explanations, I aim to make governance more accessible to a broader audience, fostering informed discussions and facilitating better understanding of the underlying technologies and their implications.

Detail as follows：

https://github.com/tmelhao/blocktech-demystified

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
I have over 100,000 readers across my media channels and have produced hundreds of articles related to technology analysis.

I possess unique insights into the trends and developments in the Layer 2 industry, and I have closely followed and analyzed the technical iterations and market collaboration plans of OP Stack. 

My goal is to help the market gain a more objective and comprehensive understanding of the industry value of OP Stack.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Fractal Democracy: We've pioneered implementation of fractal governance structures, providing a scalable model for decentralized decision-making that could enhance all Optimism governance.

Prosocial Game Experimentation: We’ve designed and tested various iterations of onchain social games and consensus processes, fostering collaborative product and strategy development for collective decision-making processes on Optimism.

Governance Tool Development: We've facilitated discussions and demonstrations of various governance tools, supporting their development and integration into communities interested in them across the Optimism ecosystem and beyond.

Governance Knowledge Hub: We host and record discussions with diverse blockchain governance leaders, building a rich educational resource for governance innovation and strategy.

Our consistent events have provided a stable environment for ongoing governance experimentation, contributing to the evolution of Optimism's governance landscape

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Governance Innovation Incubation: By providing a regular forum for experimentation with 37 events since last October, we've accelerated the development and refinement of governance tools now used in Optimism Fractal and several other communities.

2. Governance Education: Our events and videos have provided an accessible entry point for both newcomers and leaders across the Superchain to learn about and engage with advanced Optimism governance concepts.

3. Prototype Testing: Our community has served as an initial testing ground for governance innovations before their wider implementation in Optimism Fractal or the broader Collective.

4. Governance Laboratory: Our long-running event series serves as a platform for iterative improvements, constantly refining democratic processes and contributing to the evolution of the Optimism's governance mechanisms..

These improvements have strengthened Optimism's governance by fostering innovation, education, and cross-ecosystem collaboration.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Our work has supported these key governance processes and experiments:

1. Community-Driven Agenda Setting: We pioneered Cagendas and OPTOPICS, two collaborative topic selection processes using onchain reputation tokens, enhancing community engagement in governance discussions and contributing to the development of more effective deliberation methods.

2. Governance Education: Our events served as an interactive platform for newcomers and leaders across the Superchain to learn about and engage with Optimism's governance processes, including RetroFunding and missions.

3. RetroPGF Evaluation: RetroPitches events provided a platform for public goods creators to showcase their work, supporting the RetroPGF Round 3 evaluation process by offering badge holders insights into projects' impacts.

Governance Tool Showcases: We provided a regular forum for developers to present governance-related tools and innovations, supporting the evolution of Optimism's governance infrastructure.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Our work has improved the performance of governance processes in several ways:

1. Enhanced Participation: By providing an accessible entry point to governance discussions and pioneering novel agenda games, we've increased engagement in Optimism governance and developed scalable processes that can be used to facilitate other key governance meetings.

2. Improved Information Flow: Our events and video content have created a more informed governance community, facilitating better decision-making and community knowledge in various governance processes.

3. Cross-Community Collaboration: We facilitated discussions between various stakeholders in the Optimism ecosystem, including delegates, council members, and builders, fostering a more cohesive governance community.

4. Governance Innovation Catalyst: By providing a platform for governance experiments and tool showcases, we've accelerated the development and adoption of innovative governance mechanisms within the Optimism ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was created to prevent capture of the Token House by any single tokenholder or group, including protocols and OP Chains. It represents high-impact individual delegates and acts as a communication bridge between the Token House and Citizens' House, addressing imbalances in power and maintaining governance integrity.

Relevant Documentation:
- Anticapture Commission Charter
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission/6889
- Anticapture Commission Communication Thread
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501
- Season 5 Retrospective
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-retrospective-season-5/8108
- Internal Operating Procedures
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-internal-operating-procedures/7348

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) met its Season 5 mandate by representing individual delegates and preventing capture of the Token House by any single entity. It increased votable supply by 24% and initiated discussions that led to on-chain protocol upgrades. The ACC built its Internal Operating Procedures (IOP) from scratch, defining voting protocols, communication channels, and reporting processes. Regular Office Hours ensured direct community engagement, though no reports to the Citizens' House were needed.

Key Impacts:
- Votable Supply: Increased from 72.6M to 90M OP with a 10M OP delegation.
- Delegate Engagement: 165 of 269 approvals in key voting cycles.
- Operational Development: Established IOP and refined governance processes.
- Community Engagement: Held Office Hours every voting cycle.

More details here:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-retrospective-season-5/8108

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Impact Garden is used to gather standardized information on a project's impact to the Optimism Collective beyond that being self reported by applicants. The information collected is linked to the reputation of the person providing the testimonial enabling advanced weighting by the consumer of the data. Higher reputation in the Collective, can mean your testimonial is more relevant in decisions.

For Round 5, Impact Garden gathered over 100 testimonials for 35+ projects in the round. These testimonials were used by Badgeholders during the review process particularly to determine if projects were in the right sub-category and for additional information.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The audience benefiting the most from the data created by Impact Garden are Badgeholders. 

Through the generation of new data in a standardized format we're bridging the gap and giving numbers, projects and contributions a context about their impact to others within the Collective. This has looked like additional data for Badgeholders in the review process and voting.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: We have created templates for creating frames for delegating tokens. By doing so, we attracted more users from Warpcast and made it easier for delegates. More: https://x.com/zefirium_crypto/status/1795062923720573226

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: The tool is most useful for delegates who are actively creating content on Warpcast. Our tool also attracted good organic growth in Optimism, whose chain we were the first to implement in FrameMaker, and our template was the first to create a delegation pool in OP.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Each Badgeholder session has had a different focus given that the needs are matched according to the stage of RetroRounds and the current experiments being carried out:

1. Workshops on the creation of lists for 3 different categories prior to RetroRound3. I designed and ran the workshops in a couple of them with the support of 2 other Badgeholders.
2. Istanbul Meetup @ Onchain Summit where we gathered to 1) connect, 2) explore thoughts on lists and voting, 3) learn about projects such as Pairwise. Secured a place with the OP team, created merch, and coordinated with Badgeholders attending DevConnect. 
3. Badgies Workshopping @ Eth Denver: Coordinated the event, contacted the presenting teams, and led the session.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Each session has led to different improvements in the process and experiments of RetroRounds. 
For the first two, the outcomes are described above. 

For the 3 Session, here is some additional information:

In this session the following teams presented and received feedback from Badgeholders and the Foundation:
1. EZKL - https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz/
2. Buidl Guild - Metrics Based Voting
3. Agora 
4. Pairwise
5. EasyRPGF

 This session particularly informed changes in the design of voting for Round 4, the release of EZKL's proving system for Retro3 results, among other things.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Citizens House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering hight-context feedback from highly engaged Citizens during the design phase of RetroRounds in multiple levels and stages of the process. In the initial scope, members were expected to spend an average of 5 hours per Round/Season providing feedback, with work starting on April 1st for 6 months where feedback would be provided for Rounds 4 and 5 only.  

The work developed by the Citizens House Feedback Commission marks a significant step towards setting the foundations for the decentralization of the metagovernance design process.

More information on the initial scope of work for the Commission can be found here: 
- Introducing the Collective Feedback Commission
https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863 
- The Path to Open Metagovernance
https://gov.optimism.io/t/the-path-to-open-metagovernance/7728

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Citizen’s FC achieved it's mandate and initial scope of work by providing feedback to 8 documents for Rounds 4 and 5. 
Impact as stated by the Foundation can be found here:https://bit.ly/4f2s3bW

Additionally, we exceeded our mandate by crafting the proposal of a Mission Request, providing feedback for Optimism’s Decentralization Milestones, Optimism’s Product Vision, Backstopped Grants and Round 6; extending our work into early October.
Feedback led to:
1. Changes in the scope of Round 6 and it’s sub-categories
2. Increase in the resources provided by the Foundation for context setting for the Decentralization Milestones such as: explainer post, loom video, additional frameworks.
3. Feedback on the Product Vision led to “moderate edits” and was “very useful” to demonstrate opportunity areas in the communications from the Foundation.

Based on the impact generated, the Commission will become a permanent structure:
https://bit.ly/4h6CJs7

Reward split:
https://bit.ly/4h6CugH

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
OSO's infrastructure was critical to Retro Funding 4, which used "metrics-based voting" instead of the more traditional "project-based voting" interface.

Metrics-based voting had never been tried before -- let alone for hundreds of projects across various chains. The data infrastructure we built was able to respond to all of this complexity and power a successful voting experience. (The same infrastructure was also used to screen projects for eligibility and assist with open source licensing checks.)

Once the models were released, we posted an audit/bug bounty to the community. Fortunately, no issues were raised. Months later, there still have not been any. 😅

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
We believe our infrastructure has been most valuable for Citizens, the Foundation, and other long-term minded governance participants.

As the Superchain scales, it will become increasingly impossible for every participant to have a detailed understanding of every project or category of projects. Data is necessary not only to better leverage the time of experts and ordinary citizens but also to create a more even playing field for builders.

Badgeholders had many positive things to say about the experience, from significant time savings to trusting that the distribution would be fairer / more meritocratic.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer: The Security Council carried out its role of signing protocol upgrades approved by the Token House in accordance with the Internal Operating Procedures set out by the council. In Season 6 the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1, where the Foundation multisig was removed from the Upgrade multisig, and the Security Council became the sole signer.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
In Season 6, the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1. A requirement for Phase 1 is that a 75% signing threshold is met for all upgrades. This requires 10 out of 13 signatures. Security Council members continued to engage swiftly when action was required. The following upgrades were signed during Season 6:

### Protocol Upgrade 10 — Granite Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: September 6 - September 10
🥳 Status: Executed September 11 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 9 — Fjord Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: June 26 - July 2
🥳 Status: Executed July 10 with 12/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 8 — Changes for Stage 1 Decentralization
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 7 — Fault Proofs
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We developed Pairwise for RF3, and introduced category voting to make the impact measurement in the Retro Funding more organic and manageable.

In RF3, 185 users engaged, 27 badgeholders using their key.

In RF4, we expanded into a community experiment using pseudonymous voting with zk-tech. This allowed all stakeholders—badgeholders, token holders, recipients, and delegates—to participate freely without pressure and promote project discovery. We also distributed 4,000 OP as rewards, a 100OP to 40 lucky winners. Here you can find the [final results](https://www.pairwise.vote/rf4-results), and our [blog conclusions](https://paragraph.xyz/@pairwise) for more details on our outcomes.

The feedback from RF4 was very positive, leading to an invite to build with Optimism for RF5. For this round, we developed a star rating system, enabling participants to assign stars to projects before comparing them. This system grouped projects into tiers, significantly reducing the number of comparisons.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main target when developing the product were badgeholders, who can use Pairwise, to rank Retro Funding projects in a fun way that promotes project discovery.

However, the entire Optimism community that used the app discovered impactful projects, bringing more visibility to emerging initiatives.

Projects benefited from this increased exposure to potential users. Pairwise also sparks discussions by comparing its results to official ones, fostering deeper insights and driving more meaningful participation and progress to decentralization.

The foundation’s implementation of RetroFunding was clearly informed by our work and [feedback](https://gov.optimism.io/t/retropgf-round-3-feedback-thread/6177/150?u=griff). Enabling categorical voting, and ranking projects then adjusting percentages were done in Pairwise before they were considered to be implemented in RF5&RF6. Subtracting grant amounts and soliciting comments from badgeholders were also inspired by our work, but cut from scope.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Our DAO has 159 unique members who have provided us with 131k OP votes. We follow new proposals every day and have participated in almost every vote.

In order to attract this number of users, we held various events and engaged in media outreach. We have also done a lot of work with CIS Influencers, so the number of participants and the amount has increased several times since PRGF3.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer: The number of active DAO participants increased from 93 to 159 and the amount from 38k to 131k OP. So we can confidently say that we have done a great job in increasing the decentralization of the network over the last year.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Respect Game: We've refined this core process, enabling peer evaluation of governance contributions to Optimism and creating a decentralized reputation system crucial for governance.

2. Decentralized Governance Structures: Our weekly council selection and proposal review processes, based on Respect earnings, demonstrate a practical model of decentralized decision-making.

3. Governance Builder Showcases: We provide a regular forum for developers to present governance-related tools and innovations, while collaborating with others.

4. Governance Education: Our events serve as an interactive platform for newcomers to engage with innovative Optimism governance processes.

5. Stakeholder Collaboration: We foster connections between delegates, council members, and builders, creating a more cohesive governance ecosystem and facilitating knowledge exchange.

These consistent events create a stable environment for ongoing governance experimentation and refinement on Optimism.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Enhanced Governance Participation: We've increased engagement in Optimism governance by providing a regular, accessible entry point, attracting over 50 leaders to actively participate in governance practices (and many more viewers).

2. Decentralized Reputation: The Respect token earned at our events has created a nuanced measure of governance contributions, improving decision-making processes and impact measurement.

3. Governance Development: By providing a stable platform for governance experimentation and connecting participants, we've enabled the development of several open-source governance tools and inspired other communities to build on Optimism with these tools.

4. Scalable Governance Model: Our fractal approach has demonstrated how large-scale governance decisions can be made efficiently in a decentralized manner in all other aspects of Optimism governance.

These improvements have strengthened Optimism's governance, making it more effective, inclusive, and resilient.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
**Discord Praise Bot:**

Allows users to praise one another within their community for contributions, which are then stored and minted as on-chain attestations on Optimism Network.

Facilitates community recognition and builds trust through transparent records of contributions.
Since Oct 1st, 2023 to Sep 18th, 2024, We had a total of 642 Praises. Each one a statement of gratitude, as well as reputational data. 

200+ Active users 



**Praise on Farcaster:**

Integrates Praise’s attestation capabilities onto Farcaster. Users can tag @givepraise to publicly appreciate other Farcaster accounts.

Farcaster Frame Praise Attestations lowers the barrier to entry for creating user reputation, contributing to proof of uniqueness and reputation scores across the Web3 ecosystem.

236 attestations minted since the launch on Praise Farcaster bot (within 2 weeks)

76 Unique users minted attestations

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
**Active Participants in Optimism Governance:**

Delegates & Badgeholders:

Can easily show gratitude
Can help community members build onchain reputation. 

Engaged Community Members:
Gain visibility and reputation through peer recognition.
Boosts motivation to participate in governance activities.
Better vibes

**Individuals Verifying Reputations and Identities:**

Onchain Attestations:
Provide a transparent and verifiable record of contributions.
Aid in assessing community members' reputations.

Trust Building:
Help users make informed decisions within governance.
Lower the barrier to entry for new contributors seeking to build trust.

Overall Impact:
Simplified the process of acknowledging contributions and verifying reputations.
Strengthened engagement and collaboration within the Optimism governance ecosystem.

impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Grants Council is to oversee the evaluation and approval of projects for Governance Fund grants, ensuring they align with the season's intent andthe mission requests.  

Key responsibilities include:

1. Grant Evaluation: Reviewing and approving grant applications that further the goals of The Collective.
2. Mission Creation: Developing and proposing Mission Requests aligned with the broader objectives of the Optimism Collective, targeting specific ecosystem needs (Intents).
3. Ensuring transparency by publishing reports, tracking milestone progress, and maintaining open communication with the community.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Impact Garden is used to gather standardized information on a project's impact to the Optimism Collective beyond that being self reported by applicants. The information collected is linked to the reputation of the person providing the testimonial enabling advanced weighting by the consumer of the data. Higher reputation in the Collective, can mean your testimonial is more relevant in decisions.

For Round 5, Impact Garden gathered over 100 testimonials for 35+ projects in the round. These testimonials were used by Badgeholders during the review process particularly to determine if projects were in the right sub-category and for additional information.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The audience benefiting the most from the data created by Impact Garden are Badgeholders. 

Through the generation of new data in a standardized format we're bridging the gap and giving numbers, projects and contributions a context about their impact to others within the Collective. This has looked like additional data for Badgeholders in the review process and voting.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of govNERDs was to enhance governance accessibility by taking on key responsibilities that streamline the proposal process, such as guiding proposals through feedback, approval, and voting stages. We facilitated collaboration among proposers, ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods, and maintained onboarding hubs for both Token House and Citizens' House. Our work aimed to ensure high-quality engagement in the governance forum while reducing the administrative burden on the Optimism Foundation, thus enabling a smoother and more inclusive governance process. 

Foundation Mission Request: Season 5 govNERDs
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem-contributions/issues/114

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During Season 5, govNERDs successfully reduced the Foundation’s workload by taking over key gov responsibilities. We managed Voting Cycle Roundups, drafted vote copy, and handled announcements for voting and veto cycles, making the governance process more efficient. GovNERDs also ensured Citizens' awareness of veto periods during the first season of Citizen’s House governance and maintained the Token House and Citizens’ House Onboarding Hubs. Additionally, our efforts in monitoring the forum, answering community questions, and providing feedback in retrospectives significantly enhanced delegate and Citizen experiences. This performance exceeded our mandate by streamlining operations and setting the stage for an open contribution path in Season 6.

Impact Evaluation made by the Foundation: 
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem-contributions/issues/114#issuecomment-2091050734

Reward Split: 
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zzsd7p2ECdHBnQQhWMt8ivArqfUIXNv713FjrCQ51mE

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was created to prevent capture of the Token House by any single tokenholder or group, including protocols and OP Chains. It represents high-impact individual delegates and acts as a communication bridge between the Token House and Citizens' House, addressing imbalances in power and maintaining governance integrity.
 
Relevant Documentation:
Anticapture Commission Mandate: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission/6889

Anticapture Commission Communication Thread:  https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/9


Season 6 Internal Operating Procedures: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-s6-internal-operating-procedures-iop/8637

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During S6 Governance (VC #25 to #28), ACC voted on the Dolomite Network upgrade proposal. ACC held discussions and shared feedback to the Foundation on the Dolomite Upgrade Proposal on certain technical aspects of the upgrade that the ACC members felt could have been better implemented. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/20 ) 

During S6 voting cycles, few Delegates encountered voting issues on the Agora UI, resulting in wrongly cast votes during a mission request vote. The ACC held internal discussions on the issue and took it up with the Agora team and worked towards resolving the issue. 


The ACC also held a call to discuss the Accelerated Decentralization Proposal for Optimism with GFX Labs and the Foundation. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/accelerated-decentralization-proposal-for-optimism/8875/32 ) 
 
Since the Start of Season 6 of Governance, votable supply has increased by 7.31%, from 89.4m OP to 96m OP.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
daospace’s analytics monitors key aspects of Optimism Governance by tracking Protocol Upgrades, Mission Requests, and discussions from working groups like the Grants Council, the Developer Advisory Board, and the Token House. By highlighting significant weekly forum discussions such as RPGF rounds and technical advancements, we ensure that DAO members stay informed and can easily access the most important updates without missing key details.

By highlighting Protocol Upgrades and activities within the Token House, we help members understand proposed changes, governance decisions, and their impacts on the community. We spotlight contributions from key initiatives and committees, promoting transparency and informed participation in governance discussions.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Our analytics work has benefited the following key groups:

DAO Members with Limited Time: We provide concise summaries of discussions like Protocol Upgrades, Mission Requests, and Token House activities, helping busy members stay informed. For example, MatthewB found our summaries "very helpful" for keeping up with topics. https://gov.optimism.io/t/optimism-forum-weekly-recap-april-29-may-5-2024/8067/2

Topic Creators: Our highlights increase visibility and engagement for all discussions, helping topic creators gain more participation on their posts. Whether it's Security Council Nominations or technical proposals, our summaries amplify important contributions. Delegates like Liliop.eth thanked us for amplifying their efforts - https://gov.optimism.io/t/optimism-forum-weekly-recap-may-20-2024-may-26-2024/8214/2

New Members: Our summaries help newcomers understand the DAO's structure and key discussions, equipping them with the knowledge to engage in governance effectively.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
RetroPGF Hub serves as the central infrastructure and governance tool for Retro Funding, a vital element of the Citizens' House. It empowers the Optimism community to actively participate in governance, explore comprehensive information, and stay well-informed about all aspects of Retro Funding.

Our platform offers detailed information on Retro Funding, including its foundational concepts, the historical context of each funding round, and in-depth insights into previously funded projects. This ensures governance participants have the knowledge they need to make informed decisions.

Additionally, we enhance community engagement by providing a space for feedback on builders' project ideas. This interaction fosters a continuous learning and improvement loop that benefits both the Optimism ecosystem and the builders contributing to it.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Several users, particularly new participants in the Retro Funding process, have greatly benefited from our infrastructure. Badgeholders, key in Retro Funding governance, are a primary group that benefits. Our platform enables them to easily participate, shape Retro Funding, and access critical project data, making research and discovery more efficient for governance participants within the Citizens' House.

Our platform is also recognized as a trusted source for Retro Funding details, with referrals from platforms like retrofunding.optimism.io (Optimism Official) and optimism.curiahub.xyz (CuriaLabs), directing users to project details for each funding round. This streamlines access to key information for governance participants.

Ultimately, our platform supports governance within the Optimism ecosystem, benefiting individual users and the broader structure. Our infrastructure continues to strengthen the Citizens' House, enhancing its ability to effectively of Retro Funding.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The **Delegate Match Farcaster Frame** is designed to improve accessibility in Optimism governance by helping OP token holders find active delegates who align with their values and vision. The tool streamlines the process, allowing users to take an 11-question survey and match with active, values-aligned delegates, increasing the overall votable OP supply. [Landing page](https://delegatematch.xyz/)

Leveraging Farcaster’s 650K registered users and 60-100K daily active users, Delegate Match boosts exposure to the OP delegation process. Our Farcaster Frame provides a seamless experience, enabling users to make an informed decision and delegate their tokens in just five minutes. By integrating the Ethereum Attestation Service, Delegate Match supports delegate reputation-building. It provides OP holders and delegates a low-cost, high-impact, innovative delegation tool. [Onchain Metrics](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/rJaRn0UJJe)

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main beneficiaries of **Delegate Match** are OP token holders who aren’t too engaged in governance and OP delegates with active delegations. Holders can easily find and delegate or redelegate to active delegates who align with their values. OP delegates, particularly underrepresented ones, benefit from increased visibility to grow their delegations based on values alignment rather than popularity. By encouraging broader participation, Delegate Match helps decentralize governance and promotes greater equity among delegates, enabling them to play a more meaningful role in Optimism's decision-making.

We have a solid foundation and are passionately engaged in exploring innovative solutions in this uncharted territory. Our impact included critical inquiries into user experience, impact tracking, and outreach strategies so that delegation is informed, accessible, accountable, and efficient for all stakeholders. Delve into our [Vision and Insights](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/HJaVrJw1ye)

impactStatement.answer: Our tool boosts governance participation by displaying active proposals in social feeds, making it easier for Delegates and Citizens to stay informed and participate in Optimism Governance. By integrating the alerts into mainstream platforms, our widget improves the accessibility of Optimism’s governance infrastructure.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: The primary beneficiaries of our project are Delegates and Citizens involved in Optimism Governance. They benefit from instant access to active proposals directly in their social feeds, allowing them to stay informed and ensure they don’t miss important votes.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Gitcoin developed the voting interfaces for Retrofunding 4 & Retrofunding 5, which were used by badgeholders to allocate funds during those rounds. We worked closely with Agora, who powered the API, and Optimism, who outlined the requirements and provided designs.

For RF4, we worked closely with Open Source Observer and Optimism to implement new metrics-based discovery, selection, and weighting. Our solution allowed users to filter and evaluate projects based on various impact metrics. 

For both RF 4 & RF5, we created a user-friendly interface for governance participants to allocate their votes. 

These tools are primarily used within Optimism Governance to support the Retroactive Public Goods Funding process, which is a crucial part of Optimism's governance model. They aim to make the process of discovering, evaluating, and voting for projects more efficient, transparent, and user-friendly for governance participants.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The direct benefits are the Optimism badgeholders and recipients of Retrofunding. During RF4, 108 out of 133 badgeholders participated. $10M OP tokens were allocated to 207 projects. 

Though RF5 is still ongoing at the time of this application, participation is high. Badgeholders are expected to allocate between 2-8m OP tokens to up to 89 projects.

The team has also integrated these features into EasyRetroPGF.xyz, which makes them available to a wider range of users involved in Optimism's governance processes. The SUNNYS Awards have also been built on this same technology!

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Optimystics Tools has supported Optimism Governance by providing and maintaining essential infrastructure for decentralized decision-making over the past year:

1. Initial Toolset: Our core tools have facilitated weekly Optimism Fractal events, enabling consistent governance experimentation and community building.

2. Respect Infrastructure: We've maintained and upgraded the system for distributing Respect tokens, enabling a decentralized distribution amongst leading builders and governance enthusiasts.

3. Council Support: Our tools have enabled the weekly formation and operation of the Optimism Fractal council, demonstrating scalable governance models and creating a well-organized governance body for the Collective.

This consistent infrastructure has allowed for the release of next-generation tools like ORDAO, Fractalgram, and the Respect Games app. It’s enabled a community-driven effort with multiple development teams contributing to a growing toolkit of fractal governance tooling

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Builders, leaders, delegates, and other key stakeholders in the Collective have used our tools at Optimism Fractal events to earn Respect and contribute to decentralized decision-making experiments.

2. Our open-source infrastructure has served as a foundation for further governance innovations on Optimism, empowering researchers and developers interested in decentralized governance.

3. Our tools have provided models and insights that could enhance various governance processes, including the Token House, Citizens' House, RetroFunding, and the Anti-Capture Commission.

4. Other groups like the ZAO Fractal have adopted processes to engage, govern, and grow their communities on the Superchain. 

Our tools have created a vibrant testbed for governance innovations, benefiting anyone interested in exploring and contributing to decentralized decision-making processes on Optimism, and providing valuable data and experiences that can inform the evolution of the Collective's governance.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
During this period, we introduced decentralized voting and analytics tools that have made governance processes more accessible and transparent. These tools empowered community members to actively participate in governance, which helped increase the number of informed and engaged participants within the OP ecosystem. The workshops and interactive sessions held during these events also provided a platform for new governance leaders to emerge, which has contributed to a more diverse and resilient governance structure.

We gathered valuable feedback and insights from participants, which we analyzed and shared with the  community. This data has informed the ongoing development and refinement of OP governance frameworks, supporting greater accountability and responsiveness within the governance processes. By actively involving the community in this period, our projects have helped lay a stronger foundation for a collaborative and adaptive governance environment on Optimism.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Our facilitation work during Lagos Blockchain Week and the Base Onchain Buildathon has progressively improved the performance of governance processes by introducing tools and gathering insights that make governance more inclusive, transparent, and efficient. With the hackathon projects on beta, participants will have more accessible means to engage with governance, fostering greater understanding and involvement.

As we continue gathering feedback and refining these tools, we are actively contributing to the evolution of Optimism's governance frameworks. This ongoing process enables us to identify and address governance challenges in real time, which gradually enhances accountability and responsiveness. By iterating on these insights, we are moving towards a more data-driven governance environment that aligns better with community needs, ultimately contributing to a more dynamic and effective governance structure within Optimism.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer: The Security Council carried out its role of signing protocol upgrades approved by the Token House in accordance with the Internal Operating Procedures set out by the council. In Season 6 the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1, where the Foundation multisig was removed from the Upgrade multisig, and the Security Council became the sole signer.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
In Season 6, the Optimism Security Council progressed from Phase 0 to Phase 1. A requirement for Phase 1 is that a 75% signing threshold is met for all upgrades. This requires 10 out of 13 signatures. Security Council members continued to engage swiftly when action was required. The following upgrades were signed during Season 6:

### Protocol Upgrade 10 — Granite Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: September 6 - September 10
🥳 Status: Executed September 11 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 9 — Fjord Network Upgrade
✅ SC signing: June 26 - July 2
🥳 Status: Executed July 10 with 12/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 8 — Changes for Stage 1 Decentralization
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures
### Protocol Upgrade 7 — Fault Proofs
✅ SC signing: June 5 - June 8
🥳 Status: Executed June 10 with 10/13 signatures
